I. De septem sacramentis. De psalmo, Exercitatus sum et defecit spiritus. Square and round brackets denote editorial insertions or emendations. 1 Sonderliche his man astoned In his owene mende, Wanne he not? neuer wannes he comþe, Ne wider he schel wende; And more, Þet al his lyf his here imengde Wiþe sorwe and eke wiþe sore. 2 And wanne he deiþe, ne mey me wite Woder he comeþ to wisse; Bote as a stock þer liþe þet body, Wiþe-þoute alle manere blisse. Wat þenkeste? And hondred winter ?ef a leueþe, Þat his lyf mid þe lengeste. 3 Onneþe creft eny þat stat, Ac some crefteþ þat halue; And for siknesse lechecreft, And for þe goute sealue Me makeþe; For wanne man drawiþ in-to oldeward, Wel ofte his bones akeþ. 4 And be a man neuer so sprind, ?ef he schel libbe to elde, Be him wel siker, þer-to he schel, And his deþes dette ?elde; To gile ?et meni ?ong man weneþ longe leue, And leueþ wel litle wyle. 5 Þos we beþ al awey-ward, Þat scholde her byleue; And ?et me seiþ ydemyd we beþe In Adam and ine Eue Te helle: Wa?t hope his here of sauuement Now time his for to telle. 6 Me seiþe þe ri?te wone?yng Ine heuene hyt his to manne; Ac heuene his hei?e, and we beþ heuy, Howe scholde we þider þanne? Bi leddre. Howe mey þat be? wo dar þer-oppe stei?e, For dou?te of fotes bleddre? 7 Man, þy laddre nys nau?t of wode Þat may to heuene leste; Ac on þer his, þat iakob isei?e Þer he sleppe inne hys reste. Now schewe þis: Þis ilke laddre is charite, Þe stales gode þeawis. 8 Her-on ihesus stawe vppe bi-fore, Al for to teche ous sty?e; Nowe hy?e, man, and folwe wel, A-doun þat þou ne sy?e By-weyled; For yf þou nelt nau?t climme þos, Of heuene þou hest yfayled. 9 And þat man louye god and man, Ase charite hyt hoteþ; Þat he so wel yþeawed be, Þat alle men hit noteþe: Wat þanne? ?et senne-les ne may he nau?t be, Ac a deyþe, and he not wanne. 10 Of brokele kende his þat he deiþe, For hy ne mo?e nau?t dury; And aldey he to senne falleþ, Her ne mo?e nau?t pury Of serewnessche. ?et hope þou wel, man, for al þis, Þat go?de lyf wole þe wessche. 11 For deþe ne falt nau?t into wanhope, For god him self for þe deide; Þe þridde day he aros a?eyn Of þe þrou? þer men hine leyde, Ine tokene Þat, man, þi body arise schel Of deiþe, nan more to blokne. 12 Þe bible seyþe þat mannys blod Hys ry?t þer saule giste; And water wasscheþ þe felthe a-wey, Þer me wesscheþ by liste Þe on-sounde: To wesschen ous cryst schedde his blod And water out of hys wonde. 13 Here-of spronge þe sacremens Of holy chyrche digne; And his to segge sacrement Of holy þynge signe. For gode, Hou my?te fayrer signe be Þane of þe water and blode? 14 Man, þorwe þat blod þi soule his bou?t Fram þe fendes powere; And þorwe þat water iwessche þart Of þyne sennes here. Nou loke, ?oure Cristendom his tokene þrof Of criste þat we toke. 15 For, ?ef þou uangest þane cristendom, And for þan bi-lef[s]t clene, Þou schelt be marked to þet stede To wichen heuen his ymene; To soþe, Wanne þe bisschop bisschopeþ þe, Tokene of marke he set to þe. 16 Ac cristendom hys sacrement Of so grete powere, Þat hit þorwe wasscheþ þane man Of senne alle manere; And glorie Hit scheppeþ, ?ef man deyþe, And schilt fram purgatorie. 17 And—for we beþ of nonn power To weryen ous fram schame— Þer der no fend acombry ous, Crist is mid ous to-same(s); And neade: Tokene þer-of his goddes bodi At cherche ine forme of brede. 18 And ?et,—for man his so brotel Ine his owene kende— Þa? he torni to senne a?en Þorwe fondyng of þe feende, By chaunce Þat he may come to stat a-?eyn Þorwe bare repentaunce. 19 Her-of we habbeþ tokene gode, Wanne we fangeþ penaunce For sennes þat we habbeþ ido?, To pynes allegaunce Ine fere; For þer we scholde hit vnder-go, Bote we pinede hit here. 20 Þat man ne falle ine wanhope A-last wiþ-oute bote, Al þat he heþ iseneged her Wiþ honden and wiþ fo?te, Wyþ þoute, Mouþe, nase, and earen, and wiþ si?t, Eliinge brengeþ hit to nou?te. 21 ?et some heþe suche deuocioun, Þat hym þingþe he his al ydel For to libbe commun lif, Bote ?ef he hedde a brydel; Wet þinge Of harder stat god graunteþ, Wel tokne þrow? his ordini[n]ge. 22 ?et, þa? man mowe nau?t lecherie Forbere to donne ine dede, ?et ne schal he nau?t be for-lore, For god ?efþe hym to rede Spousynge; Tokene þrof his þe wedding At cherche, and biterewþing. 23 Cristendom, and bisschoppying, Penauns, and eke spousinge, Godes body ine forme of bred, Ordre, and Aneliinge, Þes seuene Heþ holicherche sacremens, Þat beþ tokenen of heuene. 24 God wescht, and markeþ, and for?efþ, And ioyneþ men an wyues, And freuereþ þorwe his body man, And grace sent, and lyues. ?e, wanne? Wanne we takeþ þe sacremens, Þar we seþ hit þanne. 25 Þa? we ne mowe hyt nau?t ise, Ne forþe ine bodie iurede, We seþe hit wel ine oure fey, And fredeþ hit at nede Wel e?aþe: God þorwe miracles keþeþ hit A lyue and eke a deþe. 26 And bote he þorwe hys sacremens Ous þos bi-redde, Ne scholde we of his grace wite Wanne we hit toke and hedde To wisse; Þer-fore, he þat bi-lefeþ hit nau?t Ri?t wyt neþ of blisse. 27 Al hit beþ cherche sacremens Þet tokeneþ holi þynges, As hali water, and haly bred, Li?t, and belryngynges To leste; And of alle oþer sacremens Þes seuene beþ þe greste. (1) [D]E baptismo. 28 Cristendom his þat sacrement Þat men her ferst fongeþ; Hit openeþ to ous þe heuene blisse, Þat many man after longeþ Wel sore; For who þat entreþ þer He his sauff euere more. 29 Nou ferst ich wille telle ?ou Wet may be þe materie Wer-inne cristning may be mad, Þat bringeþ ous so merie To honoure: Hi?t mo?t be do ine kende water, And non oþer licour[e]. 30 Þer-fore ine wine me ne may, Inne siþere, ne inne pereye, Ne ine þing þat neuere water nes Þor? cristning man reneye; Ne inne ale, For, þie hi?t were water ferst, Of water neþ hit tale. 31 Ne mede, ne forþe no oþer licour Þat chaungeþ wateres kende, Ne longeþ nau?t to cristendom, Þa?t some foles hit wende For wete; For suich is kendeliche hot, Þa?t þer no feer hit ne hete. 32 Ac water is kendeliche cheld, Þa? hit be warmd of fere; Þer-fore me mey cristni þer-inne, In whaut time falþe a ?ere Of yse; So mey me nau?t in ewe ardaunt, Þat neþ no wateris wyse. 33 Al-so me may inne sealte se Cristny wel mitte beste, And eke inne oþere sealte watere, Bote me in to moche kes(ch)te Of sealte; For ?ef þat water his kende lest, Þat cristning stant te tealte. 34 Ac ?yf þer were ymengd licour Oþer wid kende wetere, Ich wo?t wel, þrinne to cristnye Hit nere nefur þe betere, Ac wonde; For bote þat water his kende haue, Þat cristnynge may nau?t stonde. 35 In water ich wel þe cristny her, As gode him self hyt di?te; For mide to wessche nis noþynge Þat man comeþ to so li?te; In londe Nis non þat habben hit ne may: Þat habbe hit wile, founde. 36 Þis beþe þe wordes of cristnyng Bi þyse englissche costes:— “Ich cristni þe ine þe uader name, And sone, and holy gostes;” And more, “Amen!” Wane hit his ised þer-toe, Confermeþ þet to-fore. 37 Þe wordes scholle be ised Wiþe-oute wane and eche; And onderstand, hi mo?e bi sed In alle manere speche Ine lede, Þat euerich man hi sigge mo?e, And cristny for nede. 38 Ac ?if man scholde icristnid be Þat neþ none deaþes signe, Þe pope for te cristny hyne So nere nau?t te digne Þe leste; Þer-fore hi beþ in cherche brou?t To cristny of þe preste. 39 Ac he þat ?if so large water Þe fend fram ous te reaue, In nede for to cristny men ?ef alle men ileaue At felle; Olepi mot hym ine þe water, And eke þe wordes telle. 40 And wanne hi cristneþ ine þe foun?t, Þe prestes so þries depeþ, In þe honur of þe trinite, Ac gode ?eme kepeþ Þe ned On time a cloþe þat water ikest, Ac ope þe heuede te bede. 41 Ac water ikest an oþer leme Cristneþ þe man alyue, Ac hit his sikerest in þe heeued, Þer beþ þe wittes fyue. Wel, broþer, Ne non ne may icristned be Ar he his boren of moder. 42 ?et gret peryl hy vndergoþe Þat cristneþ twyes enne, Oþer to ?eue asent þer-to, Oþer for loue of kenne For-hedeþ Wanne child ari?t cristnyng heþ, And þat oþer nau?t for-bedeþ. 43 Bote hi þis conne, hit his peril To þise medewyues; For ofte children scheawiþ quike, Ibore to schorte lyues, And deyeþ: Bote hi ari?t icristned be, Fram heuene euere hi weyeþ. 44 Ac ?if þat child icristned his, Ac me fot at me hit weneþ, Þise habbeþ forme þer-of A latin þat ham genieþ To depe; And ich schel seggen hit an englisch, Nou þer-of neme ?e kepe. 45 Þe prest takeþ þat ilke child In his honden by-thuixte, And seiþ: “ich ne cristni þei nau?t, ?ef þou ert icristned;” Eft sone:— “Ac ?yf þou nart, ich cristni þe;” And deþ þat his to donne. 46 Ac ?et þer beþ cristnynges mo, Ac no man ne may di?tti; For hi beþ godes grace self, Men of gode wil to ri?ti And wynne, Wanne hi wolde icristned be, And mo?e mid none ginne. 47 Þat on his cleped cristning of blode, Wanne suche bledeþ for criste; Þat oþer of þe holy gost, Þat mo?e mid none liste Be icristned, And deyeþ so: wanne hi beþ deede, Ine heuene hi beþ igistned. 48 Þe children atte cherche dore So beþ yprimisined; And þat hi beeþe eke atte fount Mid oylle and creyme alyned Al faylleþ; Hi?t worþeþ cristnyng, and þat child Þer-to hit auailleþ. (2) [D]E confirmatione. 49 Confermyng his a sacrement, And oþer þat we foungeþ; And wanne a man hit onderuangeþ, Ine saule hit hine strangeþ, Wel li?tte; For wanne a man yma[r]ked his, Þe stronger he his to fy?te. 50 And be þou siker þat mannes lyf Is ri?t a kni?t-hod ine londe; And so seyþe iob, þe holy man. Now mote we þanne stonde To fi?te: Þe feend, þat flesch, and eke þe wordle, Ageins ous beþ idi?te. 51 Þe feend wiþ prede acombreþ ous, Wiþ wreþe, and wiþ enuie; Þat fleisch wiþ sleuþe and glotonie, And eke wiþ lecherie, Þoun-wyse; Þe wordle, wiþ here fal?se scheawinge, Schent ous wiþ coueytise. 52 Ac he þat ine saule is strang, Þat he wiþ-stent hi alle, And hardeliche hert oþre men, A-doun þat hi ne falle, Ac stonde, So his ihert þor? conferming, Þat for deþe nele nau?t wonde. 53 Nou ich mot of þis sacrement ?ou telle þe materie, Þat makeþ man so hardiliche To stonde, and so merie Ine goste, Þat he ne may nau?t yweid be Wiþ blanding ne wiþ boste. 54 Hit his þe oyle and baume ymeng Iblessed, and wi(le), lestne: For oyle smereþ þane champion, Þat me [ne] schel him festne, Ne presse; And baume his riche and tokened looz Of þare holy prowesse. 55 A prince longeþ for te do Þe gode kni?tes dobbynge; And so a prince of godes ost Schel do þe confermynge, Nonn lo?er; Þer-fore hit mot a bisschopp be, Nis non þer-to y o?er. 56 Þat me wasche men ouer þe fant After confirmement, Nis nau?t do bote for þat honour Of þilke sacrement Soe here; Þer-fore me wescht and kerfþ þane clout, And berneþ him in þe fere. 57 Þe bisschop þese wordes seþ— And beþ wordes of selþe:— “Ich signi þe wiþ signe of croys, And wiþ þe creme of hel[þ]e Confermi.” Ine þe foreheued þe crouche a set, Felþe of fendes to bermi. 58 Ine þe foreheued he croucheþ hine, Þat him ne schamie boute (Bote) for to bi-knowe cristes name Wiþ-oute alle manere doute; And binne Þorwe creymie anoynt strange he bi-comþe His sauuement to winne. 59 Ac hou his hit, þer beþe so fele Confermed of mankenne, And þer so feawe stondeþ styf To fytte a?enis senne Maligne? For hi ne fongeþ nou?t þat þing, Bote þe bare signe. 60 Þe signe his of þis sacrement Mid creyme þe markynge; Ac þing þat þer bi-tokned his, Strengþe his þat god schel bringg Amonge; Wiþ-oute god fey and god wil Mey non þis þing foenge. 61 Ac nou þat wil þat is to gode His al iset bi-hinde; And þi bileaue of ihesu crist His nou al weuerinde: Vndigne Þer-fore ne habbeþ nau?t þat þing, Bote þe bare signe. 62 Ac þare children take þat þing In hare childhod so p(o)ure, Hit leseþ wanne hi comeþ to wit Þour? hare misauenture Of senne: Anon þe foend fondeþ hy so, And he ne spareþ nenne. 63 Þat deþ þat hi nastondeþ nou?t, Ac ech oþren aschrencheþ; Ac ?et, hy mowe ?et stonde bet, Wanne hi ham bet bi-þencheþ To leue, And do ham to deuocioun, ?ef god ham strengþe ?iue. 64 And þanne gode, þat his so god, Anon hi stronge makeþ, As hi habbeþ deuocioun, And hie god fey takeþ, Reuersed; And al his þor? þat sacrement, Þei?e hit ne be nau?t rehersed. 65 For wanne me takeþ þis sacrement, His soule prente takeþ; And þat hi nefermo for-lest, Nau?t hi þat god for-sakeþ, Ac healdeþ Ine stat þat sacrement ine man, Wanne he ine gode byaldeþ. 66 And as þys ylke sacrement Heþ þyng and toke hijs signe, So habbeþ þe oþere sacremens Syx?e þat beþe so digne: Crystnynge Her signe, droppinge in þe water, And þyng hijs for-?euynge. 67 Þys ylke sygne, and eke þys þyng, In oure child-hode we hyt toke; Ac after-ward we lore þat þyng, Þo we to senne toke By wylle. Amend[e] we, þe prente lefþ Ine oure saule wel stille. 68 Hym selue no man hebbe schel To þe bischoppynge; Ine tokne of feblesce of hijs goste An oþer schel him brynge And lefte, Ase he ne mi?te nau?t hym self To confermynge crefte. 69 Ac her ich segge aperteliche, Þys men and eke þis wyues, Þat hi ne hebbe hare o?e child By hare quicke lyues, And rede; For ?ef hy doþe, man and hys wyf Þer draweþ god-sibrede. 70 Of seue sacremens þre Prente ine herte makeþ; Þat beþ cristnyng, and confermyng, And ordre þat men takeþ Wel bliþe; Þat hijs, for no man hy ne takeþ Bote onelepy syþe. (3) [D]E sacramento Altaris. 71 Nou hy?t by-ualþ to telle ?ou— And so ich mo?t wel nede— Of godes flesch and eke hys blode At cherche ine forme of brede And wyne; Þat freuereþ ous in oure exil, And lyþeþ oure pyne. 72 H?e bliþe my?ten hy be Þat folwede cryst in londe, Þat my?te hyne eche day yse, Hijs swete loue to fonde Ine keþþe! So mowe we be, for ous neþ he Hy-faylled neuer seþþe. 73 For þo hijs tyme was ycome No leng to dwelle here, Þat wete brede and honde he toke, Þer he set atte sopere, And seyde: “Takeþ and eteþ, þys hijs my body”; Of soþe he ham aueyde. 74 For-wy hy?t moste nedes be Al soþe þat he sede; Þat alle þyng his ase he seiþ Þy resoun wole þe rede. Lo dede: He seyde to al þe worlde, “be,” And al was ase he sede. 75 Nammore maystrye nys hi?t to hym To be ine bredes lyche, Þane hym was ine þe liche of man, To keþen ous hijs ryche; Þet makeþ Þat hy beþ alle mis-by-leued Þat oþer þrof for-sakeþ. 76 Þe fend hym-self him maky mey Wel dyuerse liknynges, Of best, of men, and of wymmen, And mani oþer þynges, To nusy: Wel bet may god to oure prou Dyuerse formes vsy. 77 Þo þat þe bred ytourned was In to hys body selue, He toke þe coppe wiþ þe wyne and water, And seide eft to þe twelue Yuere: “Takeþ and drynkeþ euerech on Of þis chalice here. 78 Þys hys þe chalis of my blode, Of testament newe, Þat schal be schad for manye men”; And—ase we sey?eþ gode and trewe And kende— “And doþ ?e þos, wanne ?e hyt doþe, Doþ hyt in mine mende.” 79 Þo þat he sede: “doþ ?e þos,” Þe hey?e kyng of heuene, He ?af ham power to don hyt, And forþ power to ?euene Wel werþe, Þa? he ne toke iudas out, Þe worste man on erþe. 80 And nou þat power hys y?iue Fram bysschoppe to preste, And so schel al so longe be, Ase cristyndom schel leste; Ymete, Seþþe crist four ous an orþe come, He nolde ous nau?t for-lete. 81 Þa? he were inne hys manhode Amanges ous to flotie, ?et nere he nau?t þanne ous so ne?, Ase nou we mowe hym notye In vode: We honorieþ hyne al iholliche Ine flesch and eke ine blode. 82 Wat may amounti þat he wyle So by-come oure fode? Chaungeþ he au?t, ase oþere mete, In-to oure flesch and blode By kende? Nay, ac he chaungeþ ous in hym, To maky ous gode and hende. 83 And ase gode þer his hole mete, And sike hyt by-swikeþ, So his þe mete dampnacion To hem þat senne likeþ To holde; So he hyt tok and his lore, Iudas, þat ihesus solde. 84 Þer-fore ich segge a godes half To alle cristyne folke Þat, wanne hy scholle yhouseled be, Þat hy ne be a-bolke In prede; Let ounde and wreþe and coueytyng, Sleuþe and lestes on-lede. 85 Nys none of wymman beter ibore To seint Iohan þe baptyste; And ?et he quakede wel ar? Þo he touchede crist Ine þe flomme: Þanne au?te we wel ary?t to be To fange hym on-tromme. 86 Þer-fore, ?ef þat ?e fredeþ ?ou Þat ?e ne be nau?t digne For te be housled wyþ þys body Ine þissre holy signe, Wyþ-draweþ; For, wo þat hy?t takeþ ondygneliche, Hys iugement he gna?eþ. 87 May somman segge:—hou schal me so Fram þer houslyng dwelle? Wanne god self aperteliche Seiþ ous in þe gospelle— Wel mende:— “Who þat eteþ my flesch and drynkeþ my blod Heþ lyf wiþ-oute ende.” 88 Þa? þou [ne] take hy?t wyþ þe mouþe, Ne myd teþ þer-on ne werche, Þou takest hyt, man, ?ef þat þou art A lyme of holy cherche, To blysse, Wanne eny prest his messe syngeþ: Ilief hyt myd ywysse. 89 For on hys godes flesch to nemme Ase mouþe þe mete takeþ, An-oþer ase þe mete y?ete In-to þe membres takeþ; Ac here, Crist hys þat heued, þe prest þe mouþe, Þe lymes þat folke i-vere. 90 And ase þe bred to-gadere comþe Of menye greynys to bake, And ase þe wyne to-gadere flouþe Of manye grapes ytake, Ilyke, Cryst and hijs membrys, men, O body beþe ine mystyke. 91 Wet hys mystyke ne mey non wete Be no þynge a-founde, Bote wanne þer hys o þyng yked, An oþer to onder-stonde Þer-inne; Hy þat aredeþ þyse redeles Wercheþ by þilke gynne. 92 So wane þat body hym hys ked Of swete ihesu cryst[e], Me may wel onder-stonde þer By þulke selue lyste An oþer: Cryst and eke alle holy men O body, my leue broþer. 93 Þer-fore god heþ þis sacrement Ymad of suiche þynges Þat my?te of manye mak on, As cryst and hys derlynges Imonge; Þenne scholde hy at one be In loue þat scholde hyt fonge. 94 Nou onderstand: þe signe her, Fourme hys of wyne and brede; Doble hys þat þyng, ry?t cristes body, And body of quike and dede. Ac broþer, ?et ry?te body þa? hyt be þyng, Hy?t hys signe of þat oþer. 95 Vor ase þe ry?te bodyes lemes Habbeþ dyuerse wyke, So habbeþ ry?t membrys eke Of þe body ine mystyke: Þat weldeþ Hys honden, men beþ þat wel doþ, Þe fet, þat wel op-heldeþ. 96 Alle takeþ þat ry?t body Þyse men at hare houslyng, Ac some to prou, and some to lere, Ine wyl of sene?ynge To derye; Ac one gode ary?t hyt nomeþ, Þat body ine hys mysterye. 97 Ac þa? we be tokned þer Ine oure sauueoure, Ne lef þou nau?t þe[t] we be þer, Ne forþe nau?t of oure Þat were; Þa? þer be tokned þynges two, Þer nys bote o þyng þere; 98 And þat hys swete ihesu cryst Ine flesche and eke ine bloude, Þat þolede pyne and passyoun, And diaþ opone þe roude, Wel soure; Ne lef non oþer, crysteman, For safour ne coloure. 99 For þat colour, ne þat sauour, Ne beþ nau?t þer inne cryste, Þa? he þer-inne schewe hym By hys my?te-folle lyste, So couþe; Ne my?te elles bet be se?e, Ne beter yured inne mouþe. 100 For ?ef he schewed hym in flesch, Oþer ine blody þynge, Hydous hy?t were to þe sy?te, And to þe tast wlatynge And pyne Þanne hys hyt betere in fourme of brede, And eke in forme of wyne. 101 For bred strengeþ þe herte of man, And wyn hys herte gledeþ; And strengþe longeþ þe body, And blice þe saule vedeþ: And nede Þer-fore hys double sacrement, Of wyne, and eke of brede. 102 For he ybout heþ oure body, In-to os he let hys sinke; And uor þe saule ine þe blod, Hys blod he let os drynke. Nou woste Wy þer hys double sacrement: For note of body and goste. 103 Ac wen nau?t þat cryst be to-schift, Þa? he scheweþ ine boþe; To wene hys body wyþ-oute blod, By þa weye ne goþe To þryfte; For þer he hys, he hys al yhol, Ne mey me hym to-schifte. 104 Þe? þer te-breke a?t ine þe mouþ, Oþer ine þyne honden, Hyt nas nau?t he þat hys to-broke; Ensample þou my?t fonden: To-slyfte A[l þy] myrour þou my?t fol wel, Bote nau?t þe ymage schifte. 105 By þyse ensample þou my?t yse He hys ine ech autere Y-hol; þe prest hys messe syngeþ, Þe? he ne be nau?t yhere, Ac wykke, Ase þer beþ foles suiche fele, Ysawe al to þykke. 106 Ac þa? þe prest hys messe do Inne dedleche senne corse, Þet sacrement, man, be þou syker, For hym nys na þe worse; For loke, Þe sacrement nys na þe wors, Þa? þat Iudas hyt toke. 107 Ac þa? hyt be neuer þe wors, Þat sacrement an honde, Þe bone þat swych prest þer by?t No stel ne schel hym stonde, Ac derye; For he despyseþ ihesu cryst, Wanne he hym scholde herye. 108 Ac ?yf þou wylt tak hyt to prou For þe and þyne freende, Ry?t repentaunt and ry?t deuout Take hys deaþ in þy meende; Naut ly?t[e]: Þe more þou þenkest so on hys deaþ, Þe more hys þy meryte. 109 Manne, wanne þyt takest, ase oþer mete In-to þy wombe hy?t sedlyþ; Ac ne defiþ nau?t, ase þy mete Wyþ þyne flesch medlyþ, Ac keuereþ Al oþer wyse, and so þy body And þy saule hy?t freuereþ. 110 Nabyd hy?t nau?t, ase oþer mete, Hys tyme of defyynge, And ry?t anon hy?t freuereþ In þare oundervanginge; Destresse Of syke men, þa? hy hyt keste op, Ne helpþ hyt nau?t þe lesse. 111 For yf þe syke man hys gode In þe leue of holy cherche, Þe? he hy?t cast op, hyt bylefþ Sauuacion to werche Ry?t þere; For al at ones he mey be Þer and elles-were. 112 He soffreþ wel to be kest op, And ?et to be honoured; Ac he soffreþ (no?t) to be to-trede, And of bestes deuoured: And neade, Ase he by-leue assayþ in flesch, He assayþ ine forme of brede. 113 Þat body hy?t nys (na?t) þat þer comþe op, ?ef þat a man hy?t keste; For al so longe hyt hys þat body, Ase forme of brede schel leste; Ine manne, ?et þa? þe fourme of brede to-go, Þat body by-lefþ ?et þanne. 114 And ?yf he passeþ nau?t fram ous, Wanne wey ary?tt hym healdeþ, Wat ned hys for to take hym efte, Þer wyle he ous so wealdeþ? For mende Of hys deþe and hys passyon, Ase he het atte hys ende. 115 Of pure wete hyt mot be, And eke of pure wyne, Þet schel be to þys sacrement Ry?t of þe grape of wyne I-lete; For iesus seyþ þe vygne he hys, And eke þe greyn of wete. 116 And ?ef mannes deuocioun slakeþ, Wanne he by-healdeþ— For hyt þinkþ bote oþer bred An hea? þat þe prest healdeþ— By-þenche hym Of þe uertue þat þer hys, Þat non errour adrenche hym; 117 And tak en-saumple of þat he kneuþ, Þe preciouse stone: Þa? he lygge amang oþere ylyche, Me honoureþ hym alone; So swete Mid al þy wyl þer uertue hys, God self ine sacrement (ymete). 118 Na more ne greueþ hyt ihesus Þane sonne itrede in felþe; Þa? eny best deuoured hyt, Oþer eny oþer onselþe, Ech screade ?et al so longe hys godes body, Ase lest þe fourme of breade. 119 And al so longe hyt hys blod, Ase lest þe forme of wyne; Nau?t of fynegre kende chald, Ne offe water droppyng of wyne, Ac trye: So lyte water schel be me[n]gd, Þat wyne habbe þe maystrye. 120 For water self nys nau?t þat blod, Ac hyt hys an-ylyke To þe folke þat torneþ al to cryst Ine þe body of mystyke. Nou, broþer, I-lef al þys ine gode fey, For may no þyng be soþer. (4) [D]E penitencia. 121 Wane man after hys crystendom Heþ au?t ido wyþ wronge, Penaunce hyt hys, a sacrement Þat men scholde fonge, And mote. Penaunce heþ maneres þre, Þor? sor?e, schryfte, and edbote. 122 Þy sorwe for þyne senne, man, Mot be ine gode wylle, Þat hy ne be nau?t ine wanhope, Þat made Iudas to spylle; Ac crye Mercy to swete ihesu cryst, Mid wyl to lete folye. 123 And ?et þy wylle mot be so gret, And ine so gode faye, Þat þou wenst þou noldest sene?i eft, Þer-fore þe? þou scholdest deye Ine wytte; For ?ef þou woldest for deaþ hyt do, Þy sor?e hys al to lyte. 124 Þe? sor?e hele man a-non Of velþ of sennes slyme, ?et þanne were hyt nau?t inou? Þe for [t]e sorwy on tyme, Ac euere, Ase longe ase, man, þy lyf ylest, Elles senne may keuere. 125 For so, man, senne greueþ in þe, And eke in alle þyne, Ase wed schel growen ouer þe corn, Wyþ-oute medicyne Of sor?e. Nou her-on þenche, man, day and ny?t, An euen and a morwe. 126 Þench, þour? þy senne þou hest ilore Þy blys of heuene ryche, And hest iwreþed þane kyng Þat non hys yliche; And here Þou hest of-serued dygnelyche Þe pyne of helle vere. 127 Dra? into mende þet hydous si?t Of deade men a bere, Þat nadde neuer deade ibe, ?ef senne of adam nere; Bye drytte, ?et þou a?test habbe more hydour Of þyne o?ene vn-ry?te. 128 Myd sucher sor?e schryfte, man, Wel stylle, and no þyng loude; For repentaunce ondeþ þe hel, And schreft hyt mot out-croude Al clene: For ?ef a?t lefþ þat croude my?t, God so þou schelt ywenne. 129 Ne non ne may hym schryue ary?t, Bote ?ef he hym by-þo?te Of sennes þat he heþ ydo, And hys lyf al þor?-so?te To kenne; Ac manie desper to þe prest Al one by se?e of senne. 130 And vnderstand þat al ihol Mot be þy schryfte, broþer; Na?t þar-of a kantel to a prest, And a kantel to an-oþer; And þanne Tele, ?ef þou my?t by-þenche þe, Wet, hou, and wer, And wanne. 131 And ?ef þou wylt, man, þor? þy schryft Lat þy senne al a-drou?e, Ne wynd þou naut þy senne ine selke, Ac telle out al þat rou?e Tys la?e; ?ef þou wenst deie, and nast no prest, Schryf þe to anoþer felawe. 132 Ac þat ne schalt þou neuere do, Bote þe wantrokye of lyue; And ?ef þou comste to lyue a?en, Eft þrof þou most þe scryue To preste, Þat heþ power to assoyly þe, Þor? power of þe greste. 133 Þa? man on tyme ihealde be To schryue hym a ?ere, To schryue hym wanne he sene?ed heþ, Wel syker þyng hyt were, And mete, Wald ?ef he sodeynlyche deiþ, And wald he hyt for-?ete. 134 For wanne man sodeynleche deiþ, Hys þo?t þe sor?e troubleþ; And senne ony-schryue wanne he uor-?et, Hys senne þer-be doubleþ To nusy; For mytter senne þat he dede Þe sleuþe hine wyle acusy. 135 Man, schryf þe, and wonde none schame, For-wy hyt hys to donne; A lytel schame hys betere her, Þane ouer-moche eft-sone To crefte By-uore god a domesday, Amang al godes schefte. 136 For þa? man mo?e isauued be Þor? bare repentaunce, Wanne he ne may to schryfte come, ?ef hym valleþ þat chaunce So holde, ?et ne may he nau?t y-sauued be, Be he hym schriue wolde. 137 Þer-fore þy schryfte, man, schel be Wyþ-oute stoneynge, Myd herte lo?, and, ?ef þou my?t, Myd þyn e?ene wepynge; In treuþe, Þet þer be non ypocrysye, Bote repentaunce and reuþe. 138 And ?yf þat þou to schryfte comst Ine þyse manere to fa[y]re, Þe schryft-uader þat uarþ ary?t Schal be wel de-bonayre And lo?e; He schel wystlyche þy senne hele, Bet þane he wolde hys owe. 139 ?ef he þe schel anoye a?t, Hyt wyle of-þenche hym sore; And oþer-wyl anoye he mot, Wanne he scheweþ þe lore Of helþe, Ase mot þe leche ine uoule sores, Wanne he royneþ þe felþe. 140 Þer-fore ?e mote þolyen hyt Wyþ-oute alle manere tole, And do þer-by ententyflyche, ?yf ?e wolleþ be hole To liue; And to a betere be leaue goþ, ?ef ?oure prest can nau?t schryue. 141 Te [þe] mo prestes þat þart ischryue Myd alle y-hole schryfte, Þe clenner þert a-?ens god, And of þe more þryfte; Nau?t nyce, ?ef hyt ne be nau?t to þy prest Malice ne preiudice. 142 Wanne man hys repentaunt ischriue, He scholde don ed-bote; And þe ferste hys, þat he by-fle Chypeans, of sennes rote; Ase quances, He þat by-flek wel lecherye Bi-ulekþ foule continaunce. 143 Edbote hys dede after god conseyl Of gosslich medicine, Wanne senne sor y-clensed hys, To þolye a lytel pyne Þet frete, Þat he ne be þer-uore iwrete In purgatoryes hete. 144 Þre maner peyne man a-fangeþ For hys senne nede; Bene hys þat on, þat oþer fastyng, Þe þrydde hys almesdede; Ac woste, Bene hys and edbote yset For senne do ine goste. 145 For senne in flesch vestyng heþ þe flesch loþe; Ac elmesdede senne bet Of gost and flesche boþe; For þencheþ Þet almesdede senne quenkeþ, Ase water þat fer a-quencheþ. 146 To byddyng contemplacion Longeþ rede and wryte, To here predicacioun won, Lore, and herte smyte, And werche Dedes to ?yue deuocioun To men ine holy cherche. 147 Knewelyng, trauayl, baruot go, Wolle-ward and wakynge, Discipline and lyte mete, Þes longeþ to vestynge; And here, Pelgrymage and beddyng hard, Flesch fram lykynge te arere. 148 ?eue, and lene, and conseil, Cloþyng, herber?, and fede, Vysyty syke and prysones, And helpe pouere at nede, Muknesse For to uor-?euene trespas, Tak dedes of elmesse. 149 And seue ?er þou scholdest, man, O dea[d]lyche senne pyny; Þer-uore al þat þe prest þe hat To done schalt þou nau?t fyny, Ac more, For onneaþe hys þer eny prest Þat peyne set so sore. 150 For hy habbeþ uisyk of men, Hy more sette þe lesse; And betere hys forte apeched be Of more for?efnesse Þane wreche; For ?yf þou to lyte peyne hest, Purgatorye hyt schal eche. 151 And ?et þer hys anoþer cas Þat prestes ?yuet so lyte Penaunce: þa? me telle ham Ry?t moche of sennes wyte, Ine mone, Me mot ham legge lytel on, Oþer hy nolde do none. 152 Beter hys þat hy a lyte do Her ine obedience, And foluelle þat remenaunt Ine purgatoryes tense Eft-sone; Nys nau?t god to uor-lete a man Þat eny-þing hys wyl bone. 153 Þe bydde ich, broþer, be nau?t loþ To do penaunce here; For ?et þer hys here som reles, So nys nau?t ine þe uere Areyned, Ne þor? þe ry?t-uolnesse of god Nys no sen onipeynid. 154 Man, wane þou sene?yst, þre þou dest, Þou wreþest god almy?ty, To holy cherche on-bouxam þart, Makest þy selue on-ry?ty: Þos mote Make þy pes wyþ alle þre Sorwe, schryfte, and edbote. 155 Man[y] takeþ þys sacrement, And geþ a-wey on-digne, For he ne schryfþ nau?t of þet þyng, Bote of þe bare signe To wynne. Þe signe hys þat hys boute ydo, Þat þynge hys grace bynne. 156 Two þynges her-wyþ-ynne beþ, For-?efþe, and repentynge; Ac repentaunce hys signe also Of sennys for-?euyng: Certayne, For so may man repenti hym, Þat þer uol?eþ no peyne. 157 Þat was iked wel inne þe þef Ope caluaryes felde, Þo he escusede ihesu cryst, And hym gelty gan ?elde Mid sourwe; He deide and come to paradys, Na-bod he nau?t fort a morwe. (I. 5) [D]E uncione extrema. 158 Sacrement of an-Eliing Nou her ich wolle telle, Þat man uangeþ wane he ne wenþ No lenge he my?te dwelle A lyue; Þe bodyes euel þat libbe mey, And sone, hit mey to-dryue. 159 Many for de-faute deiþe Of þer anelyynge; And ?yf hys saule after hys deþe Soffrey harde pynynge In fere, So scholde hy nau?t, hedde he ihed Ry?t elyynge here. 160 For seint iames, in hys bok, Wysseþ wyd gode mende Þat, ?yf eny by-falþe ry?t syke, Þe prest he scholde of-sende To hys ende; And he schel elye hym wyþ ele, Hys sauement to wynne. 161 Seynt iame seyþe þat orysoun Of þer holy by-leue Of hijs siknesse helþe wynþe, Þat no fend schal reue Þe helþe; And ?ef þat he ine sennys be, For-?eue hys him þat felþe. 162 Þys his, broþer, and gret confort For for-?etene sennes, Þat oure foman aredy haueþ A?eynys þat we goþ hennes, Ta-tuite; Ac ?ef we ary?t anelede beþ, Hy?t gayneþ ham wel lyte. 163 Ac þanne hys man ary?t aneled, Wanne he myd wyl hyt takeþ, Myd by-leue of deuocioun, And repentaunce makeþ So digne; And ?yf he hyt oþere wyse fangeþ, Ne takeþ ha bote þe syngne. 164 For þe sygne of þys sacrement Þe elyyng ys boute; Þat þyngge hys alleggaunce of euel, To lyf ?ef he schel loute; And hennes Þa? he wende, þat þyng is eke Alleggaunce of hys sennes. 165 And ?et me schal anelye a man, Þa? þat he lese hys speche; For wet he þencheþ in hys mod Ne may ous no man teche; Ac stronge He mot habbe deuocioun, Þet schel a-ry?t hyt fonge. 166 Þer-fore þis children eleþ me nau?t, Ne forþe none wode, For hy ne conne mende haue Of þilke holy gode; Ac fonge Þe wode mey þat sacrement, Wane reles comeþ amonge. 167 A prest mot do þys sacrement, For-why hy?t hys wel werþe; And þat seyde seynt Iames wel, Þer-wyle he ?ede an erþe; ?e hit hedde Þo ich a lite her a-boue Þes holye wordes redde. 168 Þe matyre of þis sacrement Hys ry?t þe oylle allone; And wanne þe bisschop blesseþ hyt, Baume ne me[n]gþ he none Þer-inne; For baume tokneþ lyues loos, Oyle, mercy to wynne. 169 For wanne man deiþ, he let his lyf Þer þe god los by-houeþ; Ac senne, ?ef he farþe ary?t, To bi-reusy he proueþ; To oure lorde Mercy he cryþ, and biddeþ hym Mercy and misericorde. 170 Þe wordes þat þer beþ ised, Hyt beþ wordes of sealþe, For hy biddeþ þe sike man Of alle his sennes helþe; In mende Þer-to me an-eleþ þe wyttes fy?f, And fe?et, and breste, and lenden. 171 And for þe lecherye sy?t In lenden of þe manne, And, ase þe bok ous seyþ, hy sit Inne nauele of þe wymman[e]: To hele, Me schel þe mannes lenden anelye, Þe nauele of þe femele. 172 Þys beþ þe wordes wane me aneleþ:— “By þisse an-eliinge, And be hijs milse, for-?yue þe god Al þine senne?ynge Mid eyen”; And so he seyþ be al hys lymes Þat scholle þe oyle dre?en. 173 Caracter, þet is prente ycliped, Nys non of eliinge, Ne furþ of penaunce ne þe mo, Nof housel, nof spousynge, In þede; For man ofter þane ones takeþ Þe sacremens for nede. (I. 6) [D]E ordinibus ecclesiasticis. 174 Nou her we mote, ine þis sarmon, Of ordre maky sa?e, Þet was by-tokned suiþe wel Wylom by þe ealde lawe To agynne, Þo me made godes hous, And ministres þer-inne. 175 God ches folk specialliche Hys holy folk amonge; Þat was þe kenred of leuy, Offyce for to fonge Ase broþeren, For to seruy ine godes house By-fore alle þe noþeren. 176 To segge hys ‘leuy’ an englysch, ‘Fram þe noþeren ytake’; So beþ of ordre itake men, Ase wyte fram þe blake Of lyue: Gode ?eue al yordrede men Wolde ary?t her-of schryue. 177 Ase þer beþ of þe holy gost ?eftes ry?t folle seuene, So þer beþ ordres folle seuene, Þat made cryst of heuene An erþe, And hedde hys ek ine hys monheþ, To keþen hy wel werþe. 178 Þe ferste hys ‘doreward’ ycleped, Þe secunde ‘redynge,’ Þe þrydde hys icleped ‘coniurement’ A?enys þe foule þynge to werie þe; Þe ferþe ‘acolyt’ hys to segge y-wys, Tapres to bere wel worþe. 179 Þe ordre fifte ycleped hys Þe ordre of ‘sudeakne,’ And hys þe syxte al-so ycleped Þe holy ordre of ‘dekene’; (And) þe greste Þe seuen[d]e hys, and hys yclyped Þe holy ordre of ‘prest[e].’ 180 Ine þe elde lawe synagoge ferst God let the ordres werche, And þat was sched of þat hys ly?t Nou wro?t ine holy cherche; Iuere Ich schel telle hou hyt was þer, And hou hyt hys now here. (I. 6. i) [D]E hostiariis. 181 Ine þe ealde lawe dore-ward Lokede dore and gate, Þat þer ne scholde on-clene þyng Ry?t non entry þer-ate, Wel couþe: So doþ þes dore-wardes ek Ine holy cherche nouþe. 182 And ?ef eny oþer hyt doþ, Nys hyt ordre, ac ileaue To helpe, wane þer nede iualþ; Ac me ne schal nau?t reaue Þe office, Wyþ-oute leue to don hyt: Ne be no man so nice. 183 Þe bisschop, wanne he ordreþ þes, Takþ hym þe cherche key?e, And seyþ:—“takeþ and doþ fol wel, Ase, wane ?e scholle deye, Scholde ?elde Acounte of þet hys þer-onder clos:” Hardyst þet, wo-so hyt felde. 184 Ine þe temple swete ihesus Þyse ordre tok at ones, Þo þat he makede a baleys, And bet out for þe nones, Ymene, Þo þat bou?te and sealde ine godes hous, Þat hys a hous of bene. (I. 6. ii) [D]E lectoribus 185 Nou ich habbe of þe ferste yteld, Þat oþer wyl ich trye. Ine þe alde la?e þe redere Rede þe prophessye, By wokke; So schulle þe rederes now Hyrede, and conne on-lowke. 186 Þer-fore, ere hy þys ordre haue, Me schel hy wel assaye, Of þat hy redeþ þat hy wel Ham conne aueye; For-bede Oþe-ren to reden schal me no?t, Ac soffry hyt for nede. 187 Þyse ordre swete ihesu cryst Kedde wel þat he hadde, Þo he toke ysaies bok Ine þe synagoge, and radde Wet welle. Wet he þer redde, þou my?t se Ine seynt lukes god-spelle. 188 Þe bysschop, wenne he ordreþ þes, Þe redyng bok hym takeþ, And seyþ:—“tak and by-come redere Of word þat of god smakeþ; And blice Schelt habbe ase god prechour, ?ef þou wolt do þyne offyce.” (I. 6. iii) [D]E exorcistis. 189 Þe þrydde ordre [hys] coniurement, And was ine þe ealde la?e To dryue out deuelyn out of men Fram god þat were dra?e Alyue; Þanne he mot habbe a clene gost, Þat schal þe on-clene out-dryue. 190 Þe bisschop, wane he ordreþ þes, Takþ ham bok of Cristnynge, Oþer of oþer coniuremens A?eyns þe foule þynge, And seggeþ:— “Takeþ power to legge hand Ouer ham þat fendes op biggeþ.” 191 Þyse ordre, swete ihesu cryst kedde Wel þat he hedde, Þo he drof deuelen out of men Þat hym wel sore dredde. Þe apryse Ine þe elde la?e hyt ferst by-gan Kyng salomon, þe wyse. (I. 6. iv) [D]E accolitis. 192 Þe Ordre ferþe, accolyt hys, To bere tapres aly?te, Wanne me schel rede þe gospel, Oþer offry oure dryte, To þenche Þat þet ly?t by-tokneþ þat ly?t Þet noþyng may quenche. 193 And wanne þat he yordred hys, Þe bisschop schel hym teche Hou he schel lokke cherche ly?t, And wyne and water areche To synge; In tokne, taper and crowet To hand me schal hym brynge. 194 Þet þys ordre hedde ihesus We habbeþ wel a-founde, By þet he seyde:—“ich [a]m þat ly?t Of alle þer wordle rounde A-boute; Wo-so lokeþ, ne geþ he nau?t derk, Ac ly?t ine lyues route.” 195 Ine þe elde temple tokne was Of þe ordre of acolytes, Þo certeyne men ly?te þat ly?t, Ase þe la?e ?ef þe rytes So brode; Of weche ly?t hys ywryte Ine þe boke of exode. (I. 6. v.) [D]E subdiaconis. 196 Þe ordre fifte, sudeakne hys, Þat chastete en-ioy[n]eþ; For sudeakne bereþ þe chalys To þe auter and aloyneþ, Ande weldeþ Al bare, and eke þe corperaus Onder þe deakne uealdeþ. 197 Ine þe alde lawe y-hote hyt hys, Þat hy ham scholde clensy Þat bere þat uessel of god, And myd water bensy: By ry?tte, Clenne schel he in herte be Þat schal þe chalys di?te. 198 And wanne þat he yordred hys, He takeþ þe chalys bare, And he auangeþ a crowet eke, And a towaylle nare Iuere; For he schel honden helde weter Þat serueþ to þe autere. 199 Þo hym wyþ a schete ihesus After soper bygerte, And water in ta bacyn Myd a wel mylde herte, And wesschte Al hys apostlene ueet, Þos ordre forþe he lesschte. (I. 6. vi.) [D]E diaconis. 200 Nou of þe sixte telle ich schel, Þat hys þe ordre of deakne, Þet hys of more perfeccioun Þane hys ordre of sudeakne; He bryngeþ To honde þet þe prest schel haue, Wanne he þe masse singeþ. 201 Ine þe ealde lawe beren hy Þe hoche of holy crefte, And nou þe stole a-fongeþ hy Ope here scholder lefte, To agynne, And so for þane trauaylle her Þe ry?t half for to wynne. 202 And at ordres auangeþ hy Þe bok of þe godspelle, For þan, to rede þe gospel, And sarmoun for to telle, Ta-wak Hy þet slepeþ ine senne slep, Amendement to maky. 203 Þyse ordre swete ihesu cryst Ine hys trauayle kedde, Þo he prechinde þet folk To ry?tte weye ledde; Þe þridde Was, þo he wakede hym self Þe apostles for to bydde. (I. 6. vii.) [D]E presbiteris. 204 Þe seuende ordre hys of þe prest, An hys icleped þe ealde, Bote nau?t of ?eres, ac of wyt, Ase holy wryt ous tealde; For ?eres Ne makeþ so nau?t þane prest ald, Ac sadnesse of maneres. 205 And wanne he y-ordred hys, Hym falþ an holy gyse: Hys honden beþ anoynte boþe Þor?-out a crowche wyse, Ta-fonge Þer-inne godes o?en flesch, Þat fode is to þe stronge. 206 He takþ þe helye inne of eyþer half Yioyned atte breste, Þet no god hap ne he?i hyne, Ne non harm hyne don deste In mode, Ac þenche on hym þat þolede deaþ For ous op-one þe roude. 207 He takþ þe chalys wyþ þe wyne, And brede of þe pateyne; He heþ power to sacry hyt, And þet þrof hys þer seyne Wel trewe. Inne þe elde lawe þe ordre agan, Ine tokne of þyssere newe. 208 Cryst kedde þat he hys a prest Ry?t in double manere: Þat on, þo he sacrede hys body, Þer he set atte sopere; Þet oþer, Þo he an rode offrede hys body For ous, my leue broþer. [D]E prima tonsura. 209 To þys ordre crounebet Ys an apparyllyng, Þat hys in holy cherche y-cleped wel Þe furste scherynge Of clerke; Clerke hys to segge an englysch, ‘Eyr of godes werke.’ 210 Ac godes werk an erþe was Þe puple for to teche; And also þour? hys holy deþe Of sennes he was leche: Þes werkes Men takeþ after ihesu cryst, Wanne hy by-comeþ clerkes. 211 And ?yf hy douþ wel hare deuer Ine þysse heritage, Ne may hem falle after þys lyf Non oun-worþ desparage; To wysse, Ry?t ymarissched schelle hy be In heuene-ryche blysse. 212 Þe croune of clerke y-opened hys, Tokneþ þe wyl to heuene, Þet habbe mot þat entri schel Into eny of þe seuene; And sedder Tokneþ, ase he ine ordre aryst, Þet hys þe croune breddour. 213 Þer drof bischop hys dignete To maky þulke seuene; And hyt by-tokneþ þane bisschop In þe bisschopriche of heuene So werthe, Was vicary þe pope hys I-maked here an erþe. 214 Þyse ordres to þys sacrement By ry?te longi scholle, And þat mo be þat gode beþ, Þes makeþ al þat folle Be astente; Þer-fore ich abbe ondo ?ou þos For þyse sacrement[e]. 215 And nou ich wolle ondo þys eft By þe wey of mystyke; For crystene man hys godes hous: Hye mote habbe wyke Þer-inne, Nou lestlich schel ich on-louke þys, Ase god wyle grace ?yue. 216 Þet ine-wyt hys þe dore-ward, Þe doren wyttes fyue; He schel loky wel bysylyche, Þat no lykynge in dryue Þat stencheþ; Þet inwyt hys þe reddere eke Þat holy lore þencheþ. 217 Þet inne-wyt dryfþ þe fend a-wey Myd meende of crystes pyne; Þet inwyt ly?t þer saule ly?t Myd þeawes gode and fyne; To hele, Þet inwyt wescht þe felþe awey, And greydeþ þe fessele. 218 Þet inwyt redeþ þat gospel, Wane hyt hereþ crystes lore; And ?et þer-to hys charge hyt berþ Of left half swyþe sore, To abyde After þys lyf þe heuene blys, And krefte þe ry?t[e] syde. 219 Þat inwyt hys þe masse prest, Þat ine þe herte slakeþ Þane auter of deuocioun, Wane man hys bene makeþ; No lesse Nys hyt, wane man stedeuast by-lefþ, Sacrement of þe messe. 220 On inwyt mey al þys wel do, And ine þe manne werche, Ase on may al þys ordres haue Ryt wel in holy cherche; Ase here, ?ef her nys suiche mynystre non, Þys temple stent iuere. 221 Þer-fore ech man þat crystene hys, Hys wyttes loky fyue, And þenche op-an þe lore of god, And fendes fram hym dryue, And ly?te Myd gode þewes al hys lyf, And þer-to do hys my?te; 222 And wessche and greydy hys fessel, And do trewlyche hys charge, And make offrynge of hys beden, Myd wil do elmesse large: Þys wyke By þys ?e iseoþ how ech mey do Ine manere of mystyke. 223 Þe signe hys of þys sacrement Þe bisschopes blessynge, Forþ myd þe admynystracioun Þat he deþ atte ord[r]ynge; And grace Of wyt and of auctoryte Þet þyng hys ine þe place. (I. 7) [D]E matrimonio. 224 Her longeþ nou to þys sarmon Of spousyng for to werche, Þet hys þe tokne of þe ioynyng of Gode and holy cherche; And woste, Ry?t holy cherche ycleped hys Þat holy folk ine goste. 225 And ase þer mot atter spousyng Be ry?t a-sent of boþe, Of man and of þer wymman ek, Yn loue and nau?t y loþe, I-lyche By-tuixe god and holy folk Loue hys wel trye and ryche. 226 Þanne a?te men here wyues loue, Ase god doþ holy cherche; And wyues nau?t a?ens men Non on-wrestnesse werche, Ac þo-lye, And nau?t onwrest op-sechen hy, Ne tounge of hefede holye. 227 Ine wlessche ioyneþ man and wyf, Children to multeplye; And god haþ taken oure flesch Of þe mayde marye; Wel ferren Þerof springeþ þet holye stren I-lykned to þe sterren. 228 Wel fayr þanne hys þys sacrement, And marye was by-gonne Þo hyt by-gan ine paradys, Are adam were y-wonne To senne; Ac þo changede to uylenye Þat stat of man-kenne. 229 For ?ef he hedde ihealde hym, Ase god hym hedde y-maked, He hedde y-brout forþe hys bearm-team Wyþ-oute senne ismaked. Wet þanne? ?et holy stren by-tokned hys By strenyng of þe mane. 230 Hyt was god self þat spousyng ferst In paradys[e] sette; Þe fend hyt was þat schente hyt al Myd gyle and hys abette, Wrancheuel: Spousoþ scheawyþ wet god þer dede; Hordom, wat dede þe deuel. 231 For wanne man dra?þ to hordom, He let hys ry?t[e] spouse; So dede adam ine paradys Hys ry?t[e] lord of house, Of heuene: Þe gode forhorede þe fend Wyþ hys blaundynge steuene. 232 Þat deþ þat god menteyneþ wel Ry?t spousyng her an erþe, And euer mo schel go to schame Hordom, and þet hys werþe; I-lome ?het some weneþ ligge in spoushoþ, And liþe ine hordome. 233 Þer-fore ich wylle telle ?ou Þe lore of ry?t spousynge, Þat ?e ne take horedom, Wanne takeþ weddynge. Nou lestneþ Þe lore al of þe la?e y-wryte Þat holy cherche festneþ. 234 Ase to god, hyt were y-now Þat bare assent oof boþe, Wyþ-oute speche and by-treuþynge, And alle manere oþe.— And speche? Þer mote be speche, of hare assent Holy cherche to teche. 235 And ?ef þe man oþer þat wyf By cheaunce doumbe were, ?ef [me] may wyten hare assent By soum oþer abere, And deaue, Hy mowe be wedded wel ?eng By holy cherche leue. 236 Two manere speches beþ iwoned Þer two men for to nomene, Þat one of þyng þat hys nou, Þat oþer of te comene, Wel couþe: “Her ich þe take” wordes beþ Of þyng þat hijs nouþe. 237 And ?ef me seyþe:—“ich wille þe haue, And þer-to treuþe ply?te,” He spekeþ of þyng þat his to come, Þat scholde be myd ry?te Of treuþe; Ac þat ferste ne faylleþ nau?t, Þat oþer may for sleuþe. 238 And ?yf an oþer treuþeþ seþe Wyþ word of þat hys nouþe, Þe ferste dede halte beþ, Ne be hy nase couþe, As none, Bote ?ef þer fol?ede þat treuþyng A ferst flesch ymone. 239 For þet compleþ þet spoushod After þe by-treuþyng, Þat hyt ne may [nau?t] be ondon Wyþ none wyþ-seggynge, By ry?te; And þa? hyt were her ondo, Hy?t halt wyþ oure dry?te. 240 And her may treuþyng be ondo Þorwe fal[s]nesse of partye, And for de-faute of witnessyng, Wyþ wrang and trycherye; I-lome Me weddeþ suyche, and liggeþ so For þan ine hordome. 241 Ne hy?t ne may no man ondo By lawe none kennes, And so by-leueþ euer-mo Fort oþer wendeþ hennes: Þon-wyse So bryngeþ hem in suche peryl, Þat hy ne mowe aryse. 242 Ac ?ef eny hys ine þe cas, Redich þat he be chaste; And ?yf hys make mone craueþ, Ine leyser oþer in haste, Lykynde, He mo?t hy?t do wyþ sorye mod And—skyle wert—wepynge. 243 ?yt he mot gret penaunce do Þe dayes of hys lyue, And ?et þe more, ?ef [he] haþ maked An hore of hys wyf[e], Þat ere ?ef þat he hedde y-wedded hy, A goud wymman hyt were. 244 For suche la?e is þat manye beþ, Men oþer wymmen of elde, Þar suche contra?t y-maked hys, Þat mo?e ry?t proue ?elde, And scholle; And ?et of no lees þane of tuo Nys proue to þe folle. 245 And ?yf ry?t contract ys ymaked Wy?þ-oute wytnessynge, ?ef hy by-knoweþ openlyche By-fore men of trewynge, Te take To-gidere y-hoten scholle hy be, Þa? oþer eft for-sake. 246 Þat hys, bote hy wedded be To oþren er hy hy?t by-knewe; For þa? hy by-knowe hyt, Ne hys nau?t y-helde trewe By lawe; For ?ef hy were, hyt scholde be Þese spousebrechene sawe. 247 Of ham þat scholde ywedded be Her þe age þou my?t lerne: Þet knaue child for-tene ?er Schel habbe, ane tuel þe þerne. Spousynge At seue ?er me maky may, Ac none ry?t weddynge. 248 For þe? hy were by assent Ry?t opelyche ywedded, And, ase þyse childre ofte beþ, To-gadere ry?t y-bedded, By ry?te, Bote ?ef hy ?yue ine tyme assent, Departed be y my?te. 249 And þe tyme is, wane aþer can Oþer fleschlyche yknowe; For wanne hy habbeþ þet ydo, Ne mowe hi be to-þrowe. In sa?e Hy beþ icliped puberes, Þat hys a word of lawe. 250 Ne no treuþyng stonde ne schel Wyþ strenþe ymaked ine mone, Bote þer fol?y by assent Ry?t flesch y-mone Ine dede; For þet foluelleþ þat spoushoþ, As ich before sede. 251 And ?yf hy boþe by assent Þe þrydde treuþe leyde, Her eyþer oþer for to haue, Oþer word to asenti seyde, Oþe[r] swore, ?ef hy soffreþ hym mone of flesch, Hys wyf and nau?t hys hore. 252 And ?ef þer hys condicioun Yset atter treuþynge, ?ef hyt hys goud wyþ-oute qued, Hyt letteþ þe weddynge On-healde, Bote ?ef þer ulesches ymone be Fol?ynde, ase ich ear tealde. 253 And hit is wykked condicioun, Couenaunt of schreawed-hede; Ase ?ef he seyþ:—“ich wille þe haue ?ef þou deist suche a dede Of queade;” Þa? þet couenant be nau?t y-do, Hy scholle hem weddy nede. 254 Bote þat quead be a?eins spoushoþ, Ase ich schel here teche: And ?ef man seyþ:—“ich wolle þe haue ?yf þou wilt be spousbreche, Oþer wealde For te destruwen oure stren,” Þat treuþyng darf nau?t healde. 255 Sudeakne mey be ywedded nau?t, Monek, muneche, ne no frere, Ne no man of religion, Profes ?ef þat he were To leste: Of chaste[te] professioun Hys solempne by-heste. 256 Ac ?ef man of religion Be hys ryt fre wille Ouer tyme of professioun Heldeþ hym þrynne stylle, Relessed Schel hym nau?t be religioun, Þa? he be nau?t professed. 257 Ac ?ef þer were ry?t treuþyng Þat may nau?t be relessed, Ere hye in-to suche ordre came, And here hi be professed, To soþe, Hy scholde a?en to þe spousyng, And lete al þat to noþe. 258 Hye þat þe man for-leyen heþe Vnder hys ry?t[e] wyf[e], Oþer ?yf hy hosebonde heþ Ine þet spousbreche alyue, Bi dome, ?et hi my?te be wedded eft, ?ef hy sengle by-come. 259 Bote ?ef hy by-treuþede hem Wyþ worde of nouþe itake, Oþer bote hy by-speke his deþe In hare senuolle sake, To sla?e; For þanne scholde hy weddi nou?t, By none ry?t[e] lawe. 260 Meseles mowe y-wedded be, ?ef hi asenti wylle, An, þa? oþer bicome mesel, To-gadere healde hem stylle; To nomene, Bote þe treuþinge bare be Wyþ wordes of to comene. 261 For ?ef þet hy by-treuþed be Wiþ worde of nou ytake, Oþer wyd wordes of to come, Wiþ dede of flesches sake, Þer, broþer, Scel be renoueled þet a-gonne hijs, And ayþer fol?y oþer. 262 Bote þe syke in-to a spytel hous Entry, þer beþ museles, Þanne der þe hole nau?t Þer-ine folwy hijs meles, Ne hijs gyfte; Falþe ham nau?t in such compaigni To-gadere be any?t. 263 And ine þe weddynge ne gaynet nou?t Þa? þon þe oþer by-swyke, Wanne þon weneþ þe oþer be hol, And wedded þane syke, Ne-tinde: Ne beþ no þynges bote two Þat oundoþ þe weddyng: 264 Þat on hys, wanne he weddeþ þe þral, And weneþ þe frye take; Þat oþer, wanne he weddeþ one oþer Þane hys ry?te make, By-gyled: Þe lawe of god ne senteþ nou?t Þat man be so by-wyled. 265 And ?yf þet one weddeþ þe þral, And weneþ þe frye weddy; And ?yf a spyet þat soþe þrof, And wondeþ nau?t to beddy Ine mone, ?ef he by wyl serueþ þat flesch, Ry?t partyng worthe hym none. 266 And ?yf þy wyf hebbeþ a child, Wane þou he hest for-leye, Ne my?t [þou] nau?t weddy þat childe Eft, þa? þat þy wyf deye, By lawe; Ne forþe þe moder þet hyt beer, Ne woldest þou nase y-fa?e. 267 And ?yf þou hebbest so a child, Þe lawe y-wryte hyt sede, Þy wyf, þat his þyn o?e flesch, Dra?eþ eke þe godesybred[e], Y-mete, Þat hy ne may weddy þat child, Ne fade[r] þet hyt bi?ete. 268 Þet ilke þat y-crystned hys Ne may weddy by la?e Him þat hym crystneþ, ne hys child, Ne wolde nase ua?e, Ac lete, And eke hem þat hym hebbeþ so, And alle hare bi?ete. 269 And forþe, fader and moder Þat hyne fleschlyche forþ wyseþ Gostlyche for hym by-sebbe beþ To ham þat hine bapti?eþ; And heuen Þer-fore, þa? hy ham wedded eft, Ne myt[e hy] so by-leuen. 270 And ase þe gossybrede dra?þ Ry?t to ous after crystnynge, So gossibrede dra?eþ ek Ry?t after confermynge By lawe, Þat so ne mo?e hy weddy nau?t, Ne wolde hy nase y-ua?e. 271 More godsibrede nys þer nau?t Þane hys y-mene?ed here, Godfader wedded godsones child Fol wel, my leue fere; No senne Neþ man and wyf þat weddeþ ham, Godfader þe? he habbe enne. 272 And ?yf a man hebbeþ þy child, And nau?t bye þyne wyfe, Þy wyf may weddy þane man Wel after þyne lyue, And libbe; And in þat cas þou my?t weddy To þyne wyfes gossibbe. 273 And [þa?] þat lawe for-bede nau?t Þat man and wyf ymene Toe-hebbe a child, ?et scholdy nau?t Honestete so ?wene, Ne wette Schrewede tonge for te speke, For sclaunder me schal lette. 274 Þe sibbe mowe to-gadere nau?t Þe foerþe grees wyþ-inne; Ne me ne scholde telle þe stok, Ac after hym by-ginne To telle; And ?ef oþer þe fifte of-takeþ, To-gare mo?e hy dwelle. 275 ?ef þou myd word of þet hys novþe Ary?t bi-treuþest one— Oþer þa? þet [þou] bi-treuþy hy nau?t— And hast flesches mone, By lawe Alle here sybbe affinite To þe for þan schel drawe. 276 And þet ine þe selue degre Þat hy beþ here by-sybbe; And ?ef þou weddest eny of ham, In inceste scholle ?e lybbe An erþe, ?ef hy ysibbe ine degres Ry?t wyþ-inne þe ferþe. 277 And so drawyþ hy affinite Wyþ alle þyne sibbe, Ase þou of hire sibben dra?st For þan, þa? hy ne libbe; Wat deþ hy?t? Hyt deþ þe Inonynge ine flesch, Þe? non ne wyte ne se hy?t. 278 And holy cherche y-hote heþ, Me schal maky þe cryes At cherche oppe holy day?es þre By-fore þe poeple þryes, To assaye, To sech contrait ?ef me mey Of destorber a-uaye. 279 For, erþe þe banes [be] y-gred, He þat þe treuþe makeþ Farþ ase he þat great work by-gunþ, And þanne conseil takeþ, And teyleþ; Ac mani man þat so by-gunþ Wyþ grete harme fayleþ. 280 And þa? þe weddyng were maked Ase hyt mytte by lawe, ?et hyt my?te eft be ondo, And eft al-so to-drawe. Wet wyse? ?ef þer ne mey noþere kendelyche Do þe flesches seruyse. 281 Þet hys, ?ef þat ere þe weddynge Folle þat ylke lette, Þat oþer were so ilet, To do þe flesches dette By kende; For ?ef þat lettyng velle seþe, Ne scholde hy nou?t to-wende. 282 And þa? þet on bi-wichched be Þanne hy to-gadere come, Þat hy ne my?te don ry?t nau?t, Ne a-sayde [hy] nase lome, And wolde: ?et þre ?ier hy abyde scholde, To-do ere hi be scholde. 283 And þa? þat seruyse be foul, ?et hyt hys tokne of gode; For hy?t by-tokneþ þe takyng Of oure flesch and blode Ine cryst[e]: No stren may non encressy Wyþ-oute flesches loste. 284 And dette hy?t hys in spousod, Wanne þe oþer hy?t wolde; For ?yf hyt þoþer nolde do, Destrayned be he scholde By rytte To do hyt, ?yf þat he may: Þe lawe heþ seche my?te. 285 And þa? man habbe bysemer Of seche manere destresse, Be hem wel syker, hyt hys ydo For wel grete godnesse Of lyue; For elles nolde þe la?e nau?t Of suche þynge schryue. 286 In spoushod beþ godnesse þre, Treuþe, streny[n]g, and signe. Treuþe hys, þat þer no gile be Þourwe spousebreche maligne; Ac, broþer, Þat on may spousbreche by-come For de-faute of þet oþer. 287 Þat oþer godnesse hys strenyng, Þer me may children wene; Ac ?yf þat on þoþren warneþ hys flesch, Ne my?t[e] hy naut strene: On-nette Þo scholde þat godnesse be By-twene ham in lette. 288 Þe þrydde godnesse hys sacrament, Þat hijs þe holy signe Of the ioynyng of god self And holye cherche digne, Þat avayleþ; And ?yf [þon] þoþren warnþ hys flesch, Þat sacrement hem fayleþ. 289 By þyse þre hy mo?e ise Wanne hy ine flesche sene?eþ, Wanne hy wyþ-oute þyse þre Wyþ fleschlich mone me[n]geþ: hare oþer, Þe more hy hyt doþ, þe wors hi beþ, And god al-so þe loþer. 290 Ase ?ef hy hy?t my?te wel a-come To letten oþer wyle, And lesse do hyt þane hy doþ, Wyþ-oute oþeres peryl[e], Ac blondeþ, And—nys n? ned—wyþ foule handlyng Oþer oþer afondeþ. 291 Ne hy ne wondeþ messeday, Ne none holy tyde, Ne holy stede, wyþ-oute peryl Þa? hy my?te abyde; Spy, felþe! Þer hy my?te hyt do kendelyche, On-kende hys hare onselthe. 292 Hyt nys nau?t a?ens sacrement Of god and holy cherche, Þay hy nolde by goud purpos Ine hare flesche werche, By-feld; So ferde marye and ioseph, By assent þat clene hem held. 293 For þey hye wolde [by assent] In flesch by-leue clene, ?et a?eyns treuþe nere hyt nou?t, Ne forþe a?eyns strene. Hou scholde hy?t A?e gode purpos of strene [be], Bote oþer of ham wolde hy?t? 294 Ne hy?t nys a?eyns sacrement By assent þa? hy be clene In spoushoþ, ?ef hy louieþ hem, And wel libbeþ imene; Wytnesse Cryst and þys holy saulen eke, Al louieþ hem ine clannesse. 295 And ?yf boþe beþ of god wylle, And of assent at emne, To take to religion And makye a vou solempne, Hy mytte In chastyte for euere mo Seruy oure drytte. 296 And ?ef þat eyþer oþer may Kendelyche serue, Ne mo?en hy a?eins wyl to-go, Er þane oþer schal sterue; No sauue, Bote ?ef þat on for-houred be, He may de-partyng haue. 297 And ?ef hy so departed be, Chastite he mote take, So longe ase þoþres lyf ylest Þat whas hys ry?t[e] make; Nyst gabbe, ?ef he oþer þane hy for-lyþ, A?en a schel hys habbe. 298 Þa? hy mysdede, ?et, and he wyle, Eft a?eyn he may craue, Þa? þer such a departyng be, And hijs wyf a?eyn haue, And scholde; Þa? hy wyþ-seyde hyt openlyche, And a?eyn come nolde. 299 Ac vnder-stond for þet hordom Þat makeþ þes to stryue, Þat eche hordom ne parteþ nau?t Þe man al fram hys wyf[e]. Nou lestne: ?ef þe oþer oþren so by-swykeþ, No mo?e hy nou?t onuestne. 300 Ne þa? a wyf by-gyled be Of an oþer by wrake, And weneþ wel to for-leye be Of hyre ry?tte make; ?et more, Þa? hy be strengþe be for-leye, Takþ he nau?t houre lore. 301 Ne ?ef þon þoþer profreþ Wyþ any oþer to beddy; Ne ?ef þon wenþ þis oþres deþ, And he anoþer weddy: Þa? come Þe make a?en, ne schelde hy be To-do for hordome. 302 Ac ?et, nou ounderstand for ham Þat gooþ a pylgrymage: On w?ddeþ, þoþer abyde schel Wet oþer passeþ age By kende, Oþer wat þat þer be of hys deaþ Ry?t god and certayn mende. 303 And ?yf [þe] man halt ase hys wyf After þe gelt hys spouse, Þa? he by hyre ne ligge nou?t, Oþer halt hys ine hys house, In tome, Ne schal hy nau?t de-parted be Fram hym for hordome. 304 Þe signe hys of þe sacrement Þe treuþynge wel couþe, Oþer couþe signe of þet asent, Wyþ worde [of] þat hijs nouþe; And dygne Þynges þer beþ her mo þan on, Onder þys ylke signe. 305 Þet o þyng hys þet hol assent By-tuixte man an wyf[e], Wat byndi[n]g hys of þe spousehoþ, To helde to ende of lyf[e]; And, broþer, Þys ilke þyng a signe hys eke Of þyng to-forin an-oþer. 306 And þat þyng hys, as ich seyde her, Þo ich her-an gan werche, Þe holy ioynyng of godself And of al holy cherche; In tome Of spou[s]hoþ þys aueyement Loukeþ ?ou for hordome. 307 Þo seynt Iohan in þe apokalips Se? priuetes of heuene, He se? a bok was fast ischet Wyþ strong[e] lokes seuene; A wonder! Ne my?te hy no man ondo Aboue in heuene and onder. 308 And þo þat seint iohan y-se? þat, Wel sore he gan to wepe; Þo seyde an angel:—“wep þou nou?t, Ac take wel gode kepe: Þys sygne Þat holy lambe þat sla?en hys To ondo hyt hys wel dygne.” 309 Þys ylke bok þe mistyk ys Of þese sacrementis, Þat were ischet fram alle men, Wat god hymself out sent hys To tounne; For, be þou syker, hy were in god, Er þan þe wordle by-gounne. 310 For ase he wyste wel [yno?] We scholde be by-gyled, So euer wyste he þat þe feend Scholde a?en be by-wyled Þor? cryste; Ac he hyt hadde wel priue For saternases lyste; 311 Al what os com þet ilke lambe, Ihesus, þat was y-slawe, Þat onne-schette þe queynte loken Þat spek of þe alde lawe, And seuene So kedde out þyse sacremens, By-neþe and boue in heuene. 312 Þe ferste loke onleke ihesus, Ase he wel coude and my?te, Þo nychodemus to hym come At one tyme by ny?te, To lerny, And he ondede hym cristendom: No leng he nolde hyt derny. 313 Þat lok [he] on-leak of confermyng Þer hijs apostles leye Slepynde, þo þat he ham bed Aryse for to preye Amonge, Þat hy ne uolle into fondyng, Ac þat hye weren stronge. 314 Þe þrydde loke on-leke ihesus Þer he set atte sopere, Þo he sacrede hys flesch and blod, Ase ich ?ou seyde hyt here, So holde, In fourme of bred and eke of wyn, Þat we hyt notye scholde. 315 And þo peter in ore ny?t Þryes hedde hyne for-sake, And he by-held hyne þer a set, Ry?t atte hys pynyng stake, Nem kepe, Þer he on-leke penaunce loke, Þo peter gan to wepe. 316 Þe fyfte, þat hys Elyynge, Cryst on-leke to oure wayne, Þo hand and fet and al hys lymes I-persed were ine payne One-helede, For al þe sennes of oure lemes: Anon so be we anelede. 317 Þe syxte on-leke swete ihesus, Of ordre noþyng orne, Þo he a-ueng for oure loue Þe croune of scharpe þornes; Wel wyde Ondede þe lok of ry?t spousyng Þe wounde onder hys syde. 318 For ase wymman com of þe ryb Of þe mannes ry?t syde, So holyche[rche], spouse of god, Sprang of þane wonden wyde; Nou leste Hou þat was hed conseyl ine god Sprounge hijs out at hys brest[e]. 319 Nou, lord, þat coudest maky open Þet no man coude ounschette, And canste wel schetten þet hy[s] open, Þat none oþer can dette, To hopye So graunte ous þyne sacremens, Þat non errour ne (ous) a-scapye; 320 And þat we hys mote aredy haue, Lord, her at oure nede, Þat no deue?l ne a-combry ous, Lord, þou hy?t ham for-bede Amonge; And for þe tokene þat we neme, Lat ouse þy dole fonge. AMEN. Oretis pro anima domini Willelmi de Schorham, quondam vicarii de chart, iuxta Ledes. Qui composuit istam compilationem de septem sacramentis. II. Pater noster. Domine labia mea aperies, Etc'. Þou opene myne lyppen, Lord, Let felþe of senne out-wende, And my mouþe, wyþ wel god accord Schel þyne worschypyng sende. Deus, in adiutorium meum intende! [G]ode atende to my socour, Lord, hy?e, and help me fy?te. Glorye to þe fader and sone, And to þe gost of my?tte; Ase hyt was ferst, and hijs, and schal Euere more be wyþ ry?tte. [Hora matutina]. Uaderis wyt of heue[ne] an he?, Soþnesse of oure dry?te, God and man y-take was At matyn-tyde by ny?te. Þe disciples þat were his, Anone hy hyne for-soke; I-seld to gywes, and by-traid, To pyne hyne toke. Adoramus to, christe, et benediscimus tibi, &c'. We þe honreþ, ihesu cryst, And blesseþ, ase þou os tou?test; For þour? þy crouche and passion Þys wordle þou for-bou?test. Oremus, Domine ihesu christe. We þe byddeþ, ihesu cryst, Godes sone alyue, Sete crouche, pyne and passyoun, And þy deþe þat hys ryue, By-tuext ous and iugement, Þat no fend ous ne schende, Nou, ne wanne þe tyme comþe Þet we scholle hennes wende; And ?yf þe lyues mylse and grace, Þe dede red and reste, Holy cherche acord and pays, Ous glorye and lyf þat beste; Þat leuest and regnest wyþ þe fader Þer neuer nys no pyne, And also wyþ þe holy gost, Euere wyþ-oute fyne. AmeN. Ave maria gracia plena. dominus tecum. Benedicta tu, &c'. O swete leuedy, wat þey was wo, Þo ihesus by-come morne, For drede þo þe blodes dropen Of swote of hym doun orne! And, leuedy, þe was wel wors, Þo þat þou se?e in dede Þy leue childe reulyche y-nome, And ase a þef forþe lede. And ase he þolede þet for ous, Leuedy, wyþ-oute sake, Defende ous, wanne we dede beþe, Þat noe fende ous ne take. Pater noster. God, atente to my socour! Lord, hy?e, etc. [D]Eus in adiutorium meum. Domine ad. Hora prima. At prime, ihesus was iled To-fore syre pylate, Þar wytnesses false and fele By-lowen hyne for hate. In þane nekke hy hene smyte, Bonden hys honden of my?tte, By-spet hym þat swe[t]e semblant Þat heuene and erþe a-ly?tte. Adoramus te christe. We þe honoureþ, &c'. domine ihesu christe. We þe biddeþ, ihesu cryst. Aue maria, &c'. O swete leuedy, wat þe was wo A gode fry-dayes morwe, Þo al þe ny?t y-spende[d] was In swete ihesues sorwe! Þou se?e hyne hyder and þyder ycached, Fram pylate to herode; So me bete hys bare flesch, Þat hy?t arne alle a blode. And ase he þolede þat for ous, Leuedy, wiþ-oute crye, Scheld ous, wanne we deade beþ, Fram alle feenden mestrye. Pater noster. Deus in adiutorium. God, atende to my socour! [p. 79] Crucifige, &c'. [Hora tertia.] Crucyfige! crucifige! Gredden hy at ondre; A pourpre cloþ hi dede hym on, A scorne an hym to wondre; Hy to-stek hys swete hefed Wyþ one þornene coroune; Toe caluarye his crouche ha beer Wel reuliche ou?t of þe toune. V 7. Adoramus te. Ue þe honoureþ, ihesu cryst, ut supra [p. 79]. Domine ihesu christe. We þe byddeþ, ihesu cryst [p. 80]. [A]ue maria, &c'. O swete leuedy, wat þe was wo, Þo þat me ihesus demde, Þo þat me oppone hys swete body Þe heuye crouche semde! To bere hyt to caluary, I-wys, hyt was wel wery; For so to-bete and so to-boned, Hy?t was reweleche and drery. And alse he þolede þat for ous, Leuedy, a þysse wyse, I-scheld ous, wanne we dede beþ, From alle fendene Iewyse. Deus in adiutorium. Gode, atende to my socour. [p. 79] Pater noster. Hora sexta. On crouche y-nayled was ihesus Atte six?te tyde; Stronge þeues hengen hy On eyþer half hys syde; Ine hys pyne hys stronge þerst Stanchede hy wyþ ?alle, So þat godes holy lombe Of senne wesch ous alle. Adoramus te christe. We þe honoureþ, ihesu cryst [p. 79]. Oremus. Domine ihesu christe. We þe biddeþ ihesu cryst [p. 80]. Aue maria gratia plena. O swete leuedy, wat þe was wo, Þo þy chyld was an-honge, Itached to þe harde tre Wyþ nayles gret and longe! Þe gywes gradden: “com a-doun!” Hy neste wat y mende, For þran ha þole[de] to be do To deþ for man-kende. And ase he henge, leuedy, four ous A heye oppon þe helle, Ischeld ous, wane we deade ben, Þat we ne hongy in helle. Amen. Pater noster. Deus in adiutorium. God, atende to my socour [p. 79]. Lord, hy?e, &c'. Hora nona. Atte none ihesu cryst Þane harde deaþ felde; Ha grade “hely” to hys fader, Þe soule he gan op-?elde. A kni?t wyþ one scharpe spere Stang hyne iþe ry?t syde; Þerþe schok, þe sonne dym By-come in þare tyde. Adoramus te. We þe honoureþ, ihesu cryst [p. 79]. Domine ihesu christe. We þe byddeþ, ihesu cryst [p. 80]. Aue maria gracia plena, &c'. O swete leuedy, wat þe was wo, Þo ihesus deyde on rode! Þe crouche, and þe ground onder hym, By-bled was myd his blode. Þat swerde persed þyne saule þo, And so hyt dede wel ofter; Þat was þy sorwe for þy child: Deþe adde be wel softer. And ase he þoled þane deþ, Leuedy, for oure mende, Schulde ous, wanne we dede beþ, Fram deþ wyþ-outen ende. Amen. Pater noster. Deus in adiutorium. God, attende to my socour. Lorde hi?e, &c'. [p. 79] De cruce deponitur. hora, etc. [Hora vespertina.] Of þe crouche he was do At auesanges oure; Þe strengþe lotede ine god Of oure sauueoure. Suche a deaþ a vnder-?ede, Of lyf þe medicine; Alas, hi was y-leyd adoun, Þe croune of blisse, in pyne. Adoramus te. We þe honoureþ, ihesu crist [p. 79]. domine ihesu christe. We þe biddeþ, ihesu cryst [p. 80]. Aue maria gratia plena. O swete leuedy, wat þe was wo, Þo cryst was do of rode! For as a mesel þer he lay, A-stouned, in spote and blode. For-bere wepyng ne my?t hy Þat se?e al hou þou weptyst; Al hy þe se?e of hym blody, So ofte þou hine by-cleptyst. And ase he þolede þe fylþe For felþe of oure sennes, Helpe ous, leuedy, we clene be, Wanne we scholle wende hennes. AmeN. Pater noster, &c'. Deus [in] adiutorium. God, attende to my socour, &c'. Lord hi?e, &c'. [p. 79] Hora complettorij. At complyn hyt was y-bore To þe beryynge, Þat noble corps of ihesu cryst, Hope of liues comynge. Wel richeleche hit was anoynt, Folfeld hys holy boke; Ich bydde, lord, þy passioun In myne mende loke. Adoramus te. We þe honoureþ, ihesu crist [p. 79]. Domine ihesu christe. We byddeþ, ihesu cryst [p. 80]. Aue maria, gracia plena, &c'. O swete leuedy, wat þe was wo, And drery was þy mone, Þo þou sei?e þy lefe sone Ibered vnder þe stone! Þat þou wystest þour? þy fey Aryse þat he scholde, A drery fay hyt was to þe Þat he lay vnder molde. And ase he was four ous y-bered, And aros þourwe hys my?tte, Help ous, leuedy, a domes day, Þat we aryse mytte brytte. Amen. Þyse oures of þe canoune, Lord, mene?e ich þe wel fayre, Wyþ wel gre?t deuocioun, A reyson de-bonayre. And ase þou þoledest, lor[d], for me Ope caluaryes doune, So, acordaunt to þy trauayl, Lord, graunte me þy coroune. AmeN. (III.) De decem preceptis. 1 Þe man þat godes hestes halt, And þat myd gode wylle, And nau?t one by-fore men, Ac boþe loud and stylle, Meche hys þe mede þat hym worþe, By so þat he na-drylle; ?ef he hys brekeþ, and so by-leefþ, Hys sauyle schal he spylle. 2 ?ef þou hys halst, man, god þe seiþe Ha wole be þe so kende, He wole be fo to þyne fon, And frend to þyne frende; Hye þe mysdoþ, ham wyle mysdo, And haue þys in þyne mende: Hys angel schal to-for þe go To wyte þe fram þe fende. 3 Þyne sustenaunce þou schel[t] haue, Þy? nau?t a lyue delyce, Ac mete and cloþes renableliche, And lyf ine herte blysce. Þa? folk þe heelde a nice man, Þer-fore nert þou nau?t nyce; I-likned worþ þy gode loos So swete so þe spyce. 4 ?ef þe þat art a crystene man Wel hy healde by-falleþ, Syker þou my?t be of þat lond Þar melke and hony walleþ; Þat hys þe blysse of heuene a-boue, Þar holy soulen stalleþ Ine glorye þer none ende nys, Ne none swetnesse a-ppalleþ. 5 To wyte þanne wat god ha?t Is eche man wel y-halde; Þrof ich may telle ase ich wot, Ase oþer men me tealde, And ase hyt hys in holye boke I-wryten ine many a felde: Lestneþ to mey, par charyte, Boþe ?onge and ealde. 6 O þyng hyt hys, al þat god hat, Bote a two he hy?t dy?te, And þat hys loue, man, syker þou be, To louye wyþ þy my?te. Þou ert y-helde, man, þer-to By skele and eke by ry?tte; Þou þenke her-on, par charyte, By dayes and eke by ny?tte. 7 Þys loue god heþ y-di?t a tuo Amang hijs hestes alle. Þe ferste hys, for to louye god, By-falle what so falle; Seþþe to louye alle men, So broþren scholde ine halle, Wyþ-outen byternesse of mode, Þat hijs þare saule galle. 8 Þe man þat healdeþ þys[e] two, Of charyte þe heastes, Al he folue[l]þ þe lawe of gode, And prophetene gestes. Ac lasse loue þer hys wyþ men Þane be wyþ wylde bestes: Þat doþ þat manye y-schodred ben Fram heuene-ryche festes. 9 Ten hestes haueþ y-hote god, Ase holy wryt ous tealde; Ope two tablettes of ston Wyþ hys finger bealde He hys wrot, Moyses by-tok, Wylom by da?es ealde, To wyse man hou [he] schal wel Þese ten hestes healde. 10 In ston ich wot þat he hys wrot, In tokne of sykernesse, Þat wo þat wole ysaued be, Þe more and eke þe lesse, By-houeþ þat he healde hy Wyþ al hys bysynysse. Allas! feawe þencheþ þer-on I[n hare] wykkednesse. 11 Þet o table hedde þry Of þyse hestes tene; Þe þri longeþ to loue of gode, Ase hy?t schel wel be sene. Þe seuen longet to loue of man, Þat none scholde wene Ine þoþer table sete þo, To-gadere and al y-mene. 12 Honury þou schelt enne god, Hym one to by-knowe; Take nau?t hys name in ydelschepe, Wyþ ydel wynde to blowe; Hal?e þou þe masseday, Ase he comþe in þe rewe: In þese þre schewyþ þe loue of god, Were hyt hys to sewe. 13 Worschipe þy fader and moder eke; Ne bryng no man of lyue; Do þe to none lecherye, Þa? þe fondyngge dryue; Wytnesse uals ne bere þou non; Of þefþe þou ne schryue; Coueyte none mannes wyf, Ne nau?t of hys forstryue. 14 Þys beþe þe seuene þat loue of man Schewe[þ] what hy?t be scholde; ?ef eny man fayleþ eny of þys, Nys hy?t bote an on-holde. Ac al to fewe louyeþ ham, And wylleþ þat oþer wolde; Alas! wat schal be hare red Wanne hy beþ vnder molde? 15 Ac many man desceyued hys, And weneþ þat he hys helde; And weyneþ þat he be out of peryl, Oþer ine senne so schealde, Þat hym ne douteþ of no breche Of godes hestes healde; Ac he not nefer wat hy beeþ, Ne neuer hy ne tealde. 16 I-wryte hyt hys, ich telle hy?t þe, Ine þe boke of wysdome, Þat eche man scholde conne hy, And rekeny wel y-lome; And þat hy nere nau?t for-?ete, Wane oþere þou?tes come, Tys fyngres scolde man bynde hy For doute of harde dome. 17 For mannes honden and hys fet Beret tokene wel gode Of alle þe tenne comaundemens: Þat, man, þyt onder-stoude! Ten fyngres and ten þine tone, Of flesche and bon and blode, Tokneþ þat þyne workes ne be, A?eyns þe hestes, for-broude. 18 ?et somman hijs þat passioun-lyche Can telle hy myd þe beste, Ac ine hys dedes uares he Ase he nau?t of hem neste; And ?et hym þingþ þat he deþ wel, And for to come to reste; Ac al desceyued schel he be, Wanne comeþ þe grete enqueste. 19 Here-fore nys hy?t nau?t y-nou? To telle hy uor to conne: And telle and werche wel þer-by, Þanne hys hy?t alle y-wonne. For wel to conne, and nau?[t] to don, Nys naþer rawe ne y-sponne; Lytel hijs worþ, bote hyt endy wel, Þyng þat hijs wel by-gonne. 20 Þey hyt be wel lyttelyche ysed, Þe ferste heste a rowe, For to honoury anne god, Hym one to by-knowe, Þenche þou most wel bysyly, And þy wy?t þran by-stowe, And bydde hym, þat þou hyt mote do, Wel myldeleche a knowe. 21 For þou ne my?t hytte nefere do, Man, wel wyþ-oute grace: So heþ þys wordle bounde þe Wyþ here lykynges lace. Þer-fore þe by-houeþ godes helpe, Þat he hyt wolde arace, So þat þou ne teldest no worþ Of [here] blandynge face. 22 For ?yf þy wyl reio[ye]þ more In enyes kennes þynges, Be hy?t þy childe, oþer þy best, Land, brouches, oþer rynges, Oþer a?t elles, wat so hyt be, Bote god þat hys kynge of kynges, Þou ne a-nourest god ary?t, Ac dest is onderlynges. 23 By-lef þou in no wychecraft, Ne ine none teliinge, Ne forþe inne none ymage self, Þa? þat be great botninge; Bote as al holy cherche þe tek[þ] Þou make þyne worþynge, For gode nele nau?t þat þou hyt do, Bote by þere wyssynge. 24 Þanne asay þyn o?e þo?t By þysser ylke speche, And ?yf þou annourest god ary?t, Þyne inwit wyle þe teche; And ?yf þou fynst þat þou ne dest, Amende, ich þe by-seche: Þou ert a sot, and my?t do bet, And so si?st yn þe smeche. 25 Þat oþer heste apertelyche Schewed mannes de-faute, Wanne he alday swereþ ydelleche In kebbyng and in caute. Mechel hys þat he makeþ hym Her-efterward to touty, Wenne he schal hys a-countes ?yue Of ech idel sente. 26 Þenne ne couþe ich nanne red Of þylke a-countes oure, Nere þe milse of god self, Oure alder auditour[e], Þat wolle þe arerages for-?eue, ?ef hyt hys to hys honoure; Ac cesse, man, of þy ydelschep, Oþer ich wole out wel soure. 27 Þe þrydde heste apertelyche Scheweþ þy wykked rote, Wanne þou [ne] halst þy masseday, As god hyt haþ y-hote, Ac werkest, oþer werky dest, Werkes þat beþ to note: Þe wykkede ensaumple þat þou ?efst Þou a-beyst, ich þe by-hote. 28 And þa? þou ne werche nau?t, Ac gest to þyne gloutynge, Oþer in eny oþer folke In pleye of þretynge, Þou halst wel wors þane masseday Þane man myd hys workynge; Þare-fore do þe al y-holliche Þat day to holy þynge. 29 Þe ferþe heste scheweþ þe Þat þye senne schal sle þe, ?yf þou rewardest þyne eldrynges nau?t A lyue and eke a deþe, Þat were wel besy to brynge þe forþe, As hy my?ten onneþe; ?yf þou hy gna?st and flag?st ek, Ry?t hys þat fendes flea þe. 30 Nau?t nys þys heste y-hote of god For suche eldren al-lone, Ac hys of mannes eldren eke As he te?t atte font-stone, Þer holy cherche þy moder hys In fader cristes mone; ?ef þou ert on-boxom to hyre, Grace of God ne worþe þe none. 31 Þe fyfte heste scheweþ þe Þat þou ne schalt nau?t smyte, Ne nau?t ne mys-segge ne mys-do, Ne nau?t foulleche at-wyte. For ofte þe mannes sle?te aryst, Were man hy?t weneþ wel lyte; And he þat spilleþ mannes lyf, Veniounse hyt schel a[c]wyte. 32 And ?ef þer hys mansle?þe pur, As ous telleþ holy boke, ?yf eny man for de-faute deyþ, And eny hym for-soke To helpe hym of þat he may, Hys lyf to saue and loke: Her dere ?er acuseþ fele Þat god and orþe touke. 33 And ?et seint iohan þe-wangelyst Al into mende dra?eþ, He þat hatyeþ eny man, He seche þat he hym sla?e. Manye suche mansle?þen beþ, Þat al day men for-gna?eþ, & Sweche beþ in helle depe, Þat deuelen al to-draweþ. 34 Þe sixte heste scheweþ wel Þe soþe to al mankenne, Þe dede ydo in lechery Hys ry?t a dedleche senne; And elles nere hy?t nau?t for-bode amange þe hestes tenne: Þe þat seggeþ hyt nys nau?t so, hare wy?t hys al to þenne. 35 Her hys for-bode glotenye, So ich þe by-hote; For hyt norysseþ lecherye, Ase fer, þe brondes hote. And þa? þer be alone lomprynge In lecheryes rote, Al hyt destrueþ charyte, Wyþ wrake and wyþ þrete. 36 Þe seuende heste schewed wel Man schal be true in dede, Þat no man abbe of þe oþeres naut Þor? þefte wycke rede; For al hys þefte þat man te?t Myd wyl of wynnynghede A?ens þe ry?t o?eres wyl, So lawe y-wryte hyt sede. 37 Þanne hys hyt a þef, wo-so hyt be, Þat manne god so takeþ, Be hy?t by gyle oþer mestry, Oþer wordes þat he crakeþ. In londe suche his many a þef Þat y-now hym makeþ; He wenþ by chere of iugement, Ac helle after hym wakeþ. 38 Þe e?tende heste þe for-bed Þe false wytnessynge; And þat hys, man, syker þou be, Alle manere lesynge To hermy in [hys] body man, Oþer in hys oþer þynge, Oþer in hys saule, and þat hys worst, In peryl for to brynge. 39 Al hyt hys senne þat me le?þ, Bote þat men le?þ for gode Ry?t deadlyche senne nys þat nau?t, For myldenesse of mode. Ac elles, man, al þat þou legst Is deaþlich and for-brode; Þo þet hy?t useþ, ich wot hy beþ Vn-wyser þane þe wode. 40 Alas! onneþe eny man Þat þyse heste(s) healde; Alle hy beþ y-torned to lesynge, Þes ?onge and eke þes ealde. Þer-to hys mentenaunce great, Þat makeþ hy wel bealde: Do ?e nau?t so, par charyte, Ac ?oure tongen ?e wealde. 41 Þe ne?ende heste þe for-bed Þat wyl to lecherye, And to spousbreche nameleche, Þat so meche hys to glye. Þanne nys hyt nau?t one dea[d]lyche Swych dede to complye, Ac ys þat uoule wyl al so To swyche fylenye. 42 Þe teþe heste þe fo[r]-bet Wyl tou oþer manne þynge, For þat desturbet charyte, In onde man to brynge. Defendeþ ?ou for godes loue Fram alle wykked wyllynge; For suche wyl hys for dede iset In godes knelechynge. 43 Nou ich ?ou bydde for þe blode Þat ihesus blede on þe rode, Þat in te herte takeþ þys two To ?oure soule fode; And fo[l]?eþ nau?t in þys wordle Þe uyle commune floude Þat fleuþ in-to þe fendes mouþe; And so seiþe iop þe gode AmeN. IV. [De septem mortalibus peccatis.] 1 Senne makeþ many þral, Þat scholde be wel fry; And senne makeþ many fal, Þat he ne mote iþy. 2 Senne bryngeþ man a-doun, Þat scholde sitte a deys; Senne makeþ storbylo[u]n, Þar scholde be godes peys. 3 Senne makeþ by-wepe Þat somman er by-lo?; Senne bryngeþ wel depe Þat hym wel hy?e dro?. 4 Senne hys swete and lykeþ, Wanne a man hi deþ; And al so soure hy brykeþ, Wanne he ueniaunce y-seþ. 5 Senne makeþ nywe schame, Þa? hy for-?ete be; And senne bryngeþ men in grame, Þar er was game and gle. 6 And senne makeþ al þe who Þat man an erþe heþ, And bryngeþ mannes saule also In helles uoule breþ. 7 And þey man be fram helle y-wared Þour? repentaunce here, ?et ne may nau?t some man be spared Fram purgatories fere, 8 Þat he ne schel soffry þer hys who, Ase he hijs here ateynt; And her nys fer namore þer-to Þanne hys fer dereynt. 9 Ac purgatorie and helle, Hy beþ so lyte by-leued, Þat, what so meuere telle, [Men] beþ þrof al adeued. 10 Hem wolde douty more A lytel pyne her, Þane ham wolde al þat sore And on-ysely fer. 11 Ac hwo se? euer eny Þat hedde of senne glye, For pond oþer for peny Þat he ne changede hys blye, 12 Wyþ schame and eke wyþ schounde, Wyþ sor?e and eke wyþ who? And þat was ked in londe By some nau?t fern ago. 13 Þanne ich may wyssy ase ich can, Mi self þa? ich be spreþ, Þat, bote þou wylle wondy, man, Þy pyne after þy deþ, 14 Wonde þe sor?e þat hys her Fol?ende after þy queed; And ?et þe tyt þe lasse fer, Whanne þe falþ to be dead. 15 Whanne þou scholdest sene?y, By-þenche, leue frend, And þa? þy flesch þe mene?y, Þe wordle oþer þe fend, 16 By-þenche hou schort hys þe lykynge, And hou þe schame hys stronge, And hou þou wreþest þane kyng Of heuene wyþ þy wrong. 17 Þi? man mo?e þor? hys resoun Ywyte wanne he mys-deþ, ?et þer by-houeþ gre?t sarmoun To hame þat lewed beþe. 18 For feawe of ham conne þe skele Hou senne a-boute comeþ; And þat a-combreþ swyþe fele Þat none kepe nomeþ. 19 Þer-fore þys tale rymeþ Hou men in senne beþ, And hou senne by-lymeþ Man þat to senne hym deþ. 20 Þer-fore neme ?e kepe Al hou þe senne syt, Þat ?e ne falle to depe For wane of ?oure wyt. 21 Nou lyst hou man hys bounde Wyþ senne swyþe stronge, And hou he bereþ deaþ-wounde, And fenym þare a-monge. 22 Þe wonde swelþ an akeþ, So doþ þe naddre steng, And gret and gretter makeþ, And felþe make þreng. 23 Iwounded was mankende After þat hy was wro?t, Þor? þe neddre, þe feend[e], Þat hy heþ al þor?-sou?t 24 Þorwe þe fenym of senne Þat al mankende slakþ: Nys nou non [of] þat kenne Þat þat fenym ne takeþ. 25 And þat fenym was ferst y-kest On eue and on adam, And so forþe þenne hyt her ylest, Ase kenne of-?erneþ yne man. 26 So hy?t nys nau?t senne-lyas, Þat child þat haueþ lyf, Ybore oþer on-bore was, bote Crystnynge brekeþ þat stryf. 27 Oryginale þys senne hys cleped, For man of kende hyt takeþ 28 Ry?t so hys al mankende a-merred Þor? þe route of fenym, Þat doþ þat mannes body ybered Nys bote a lyte slym. 29 Her-vppe yþo?t haþ meny a man, And ised many a foul Þat on-wyslyche god ous by-gan, And hys red was to coul, 30 Þat let man to suich meschyef, Þat my?te hyt habbe vndo; Ac ?ef þou wolt by gode lief, Þenche þou namore so. 31 Ne velþe hyt nau?t to clypye a?en, We soeþ wel hyt hys þous, God te atwyte oure won No longeþ noþyng to ous. 32 For wo dysputeþ a-?eyn hym, Concluded schel he be; Dispute nau?t, ac kepe nym, Wo þart, and who hys he. 33 Wat helpþ hyt þe crokke Þat hys to felþe ydo A?e þe crokkere to brokke:— “Wy madest þou me so?” 34 Þe crokkere my?te segge: “Þou proud erþe of lompet, Ine felþe þou schelt lygge, Þou ert nau?t elles ne?t.” 35 Ry?t so may god an-swerye þe, Wanne þou hym at-wyst; Wat helpþe hyt so wrau to be, Wanne þou wyþ gode chyst? 36 Do nau?t so, ac mercy crye, Þat þe [ne] tyde wors; For suiche al day, me may ysy, Encresseþ here cors. 37 Ac be þou wel, man, be þe wo, Of gode ne tel þou nau?t ly?te; For syker be, þat he let do, He let hyt do wyþ ry?te. 38 Swech ry?t scheaweþ wyþ God aboue, Þe[?] hy?t be hyd fram þe; Þenche namore, for godes loue, So he?e pryuete. 39 Ac þench þou nart bote esche, And so þou lo?e þe, And byde god þat he wesche Þe felþe þat hys in þe. 40 And þy? þou lange abyde, Ne at-wyt hym nau?t þy who, Ac tyde þe what by-tyde, Þou þonke hym euere mo. 41 And so soum grace þe by-tyt, Ac elles þe hy for-gest; For god wyþ-stondeþ hym þat chyt And a?e god wrest, 42 Ase he wyþ-stent þe prouden, And myld[en] grace sent To libbe a-mang þe louden, Wenne oþere beþ ischent. 43 Nou we seeþ wel hou hyt hys Of þane oryginal; Nou lest ou man [may] do amys Þor?
