hys o?ene gale. 44 Þys senne comeþ nau?t of þy ken, Ac þy self ech del; Þo seggeþ þys lerede men, And clypyeþ hyt ‘actuel.’ 45 Þys manere senne nys nau?t ones, Ac hys ischyt in þry, In þou?t, in speche, in dede amys, Þys may ech man ysy. 46 He þat ne þynkeþ nau?t bote wel, And spekeþ and doþ al ry?t, Þe man hys sckere of actuel, Ac ho hys here so bry?t? 47 Ho hys he þat al beþ wel Þe þo?tes þat he kakþe? And who hys þat speke scheal Ary?t al þat he spekeþ? 48 And wo hys he þat alnewe[y] deþ wel al þat he deþ? No man, no man, ac ny?t and day Þys men by-soyled beþ, 49 So as hy beþ men, ase we seeþ, Wyþ sennes al þor?-þerled: Many hys þe senne þat me deþ In tal þe wyde wordle. 50 Of senne ich wot by þyse sckele Þat þer hijs wel great host; And, for þe fend iuint so fele, Þer-of hys alle hys host. 51 And he arayeþ hare trome As me a-reyt men in fy?t, For he sykþ gode þeawes some A-?enes ham ydy?t. 52 And ase god dy?t þeawes In alle gode men, Þe feend a-rayeþ þe schreawes In wykken þer a-?en. 53 Þys hys þat fy?t an erþe Þat al wynþ oþer lest, And ase þe fy?ttere hys werthe, Þe cheueteyn hym chest. 54 Ac cheueteyn of senne Ich wot þat þe fend hys, For wyse, and alle kenne Arayeþ hys amys. 55 And ase þere in bataylle O kyng bereþ þe bee?, Soe hyt were a gret faylle ?ef þe host were em-he?. 56 Þer-fore me makeþ prynses Þe host to gouerni, And ase whe-welen þe linses To-gadere heldeþ hy. 57 And ase al þat hys here By soueda?es geþ, Of senne alle manere Seue deuelen prynces beþ: 58 Þat seuene certeygne Þat Cryst kest out, hyt seyþ Of marie maudaleyne Þat goospel þat ne weyþ. 59.i Þe ferste pryns hys prede, Þat ledeþ þane flok, Þat of alle oþere onlede Hys rote and eke stok. 60 For nys non of þe syxe Þat hy ne comeþ of þane, For myx of alle myxe In heuene hy by-gan. 61 Prede suweþ in floures Of wysdom and of wyt, Amang leuedys in boures Þe foule prude sy?t. 62 Vnder couele and cope Þe foule prede lyþe; Þe? man go gert wyþ rope, ?et prede to hym swyþ. 63 Prede sy?t vnder ragge Wel cobel and wel balgþ; Þat keþeþ wordes bragge And countenaunces ?aldeþ. 64 Nys non, þa? som myt wene, Þat some prede ne takeþ, Ne none so proud, ich wene, As he þat al for-sakeþ. 65 For who hys þat neuere set hys þou?t And erþe to be he?? Who hys hit þat neuer yþou?t Of pompe þat he se?? 66 Who yst þat neuer nas rebel A?eins hys souerayn? Wo ist þat be nome schel, And nabbe non agayn? 67 Who yst þat neuere gollich nas, Wanne chaunce at wylle come? Who yst þat, wanne he preysed was, Neuer at he? hyt nome? 68 Who hyst þat neuer þo?te He scholde honoured be For dedes þat he wroute, Wanne men (ne) hy?t mytte se? 69 Who hys þat neuer he?þe dro? Toward hys þat wes? Ho hys [þat] neuer ne kedde wo? In boste to hys sugges? 70 Ho neþ wyþ pompe y-schewed hym ?et oþer þane he was? Nou ypocresy, kepe nym, Regneþ, hyt nys no leas. 71 Ho yst þat neuer nas yblent Wyþ non surquydery? Þat hys, wanne a proud man heþ y-ment Oþer þane hyt schel by. 72 Wo þat neuer ne dede þous He wole prede by-fle?; ?ef þat kebbede eny of ous, Ich wo?t wel þat he le?. 73 Þe man þe hym wole a-fayty Of prede þat hys so he?, Fol wel he mo?t hys weyti Boþe fer and ne?. 74 For ?ef he let to noþe Þat he ne awayteþ hy, Ich segge hym wel to soþe Þat ry?t proud schel he by. 75 For prede hys a senne of herte, And bouute scheweþ hy Wyþ kebbynges aperte And weddyng many a bly: 76 Þor? dedes of bostynge, And atyr stent and say, And oþer suche þynge(s) Þat men vsyeþ al day. 77.ii Þat oþer feend of onde Hys pryns and cheuetayn; Þat senne hys ryf in londe, And nau?t hys hyre wayn. 78 For sorwe he heþ of gode, And harm hys hyre blysse; In hyre pryncy mode Þe hert[e] walt al þys. 79 Þys senne hys ouer-nyce, Ac holde schal hy be Þe senne of meste malice A?eyns charyte; 80 Wanne loue hys here preye, Al for to confundy, And wyl het to by-traye Þat wolde gode by. 81 Onde hys a senne of herte, And bouute scheweþ hy, To harmy and to herte, Wanne hy deþ bacbyty; 82 Wanne hy holdeþ hy wreches Þat god and hende beþ, And oþere souche plecches Scheweþ wat onde deþ. 83.iii Þe þrydde senne hys wrethe, Þat so meche hys itelde; Hyt makeþ blod and brethe Aboute þe herte aneld. 84 Wanne manne neþ nau?t hys chaunce to wylle, and alse þenkþ, He compasyþ veniaunce To hym þat a-?en clenkeþ. 85 And so hyt fret and hys y-frete Euere in egrete, And wanne hy het to meche hete, Hyt letteþ charite. 86 Inne herte hys þys senne?ing, And bouute scheweþ mod Þor? cheste and mysdoynge And wyþ-drawynge of god. 87.iv Coueytyse hys þe ferþe, Ilych dropesy, Wanne al þat hys an erþe To hyre hys al besy. 88 And hou hy habbeþ hy uerkþ, And mannes herte byset, Fram gode and so þanne name y-ke?t Seruise of mamenet. 89 Þa? hy by herte senne, ?et boute scheweþ hy To mochel amang mankenne Þor? wrang an trychery; 90 Þor? ?eskynge efter gode, Þor? bor? and ?emer ?elde, Þorw wrechydnesse of mode, And neuer more ful-felde. 91.v Þe fyfte senne hys sleuþe Of þat man scholde do, Hye brekeþ god[e] treuþe Wyþ god and man also, 92 Wanne man leteþ adrylle Þat he god ?elde schel, And for-sluggyþ by wylle Þat scholde men to stel. 93 Of herte comeþ þes senne, And schewe[þ] boute al-so Hou hy letteþ mankenne Of þat scholde by do. 94 Hyt hys þorwe besynesse Þat men for-slewyþ hyt, And oþer wyle þor? ?delnesse God dede onido for-slyt. 95.vi.vii Glotonye hys þe syxte, And hys mo ine fleasch y-do; And lecherye, þe nyxte, In flesche hys senne al-so. 96 Ac glotonye entycyþ To lecherye her, Ase þat hy norysseþ Hote brondes þet fere. 97 Of glotonyes foure Þe boke spekeþ openlyche: To meche fode deuoury, And to lykerouslyche, 98 And to freche to fretene Wanne man hijs tyme heþ, And out of tyme to hetene Þat none siknesse neþ. 99.vii Of lecherye comeþ wreche, Foul speche, and foul delyt, Commune hordom, spousbreche, Incest, and sodomyt. 100 And hys incest wyþ kenne Þe lecherye so; And sodomyt hys senne A?ens kende y-do. 101 By-feld beþ men in slepe, Ase glotonye hyt bryngeþ; And ofte hyt doþ moni kepe Þat man wakynge þenckeþ. 102 Ac ?ef euyl hyt come nau?t. Dea[d]lyche senne next. Ac hou hyt falleþ y-lome ne?. Ech man nau?t y-wyst. 103 Þyse manere sennes seuene, Ase ?e hys here ise?eþ, I-letteþ men fram heuene, And al dedlyche hy beþ, 104 Wanne hy y-þou?t beþ oþer y-speke, Oþer y-don in stat A?e þe lawe of god, to breke Þe hestes þat he hat. 105 Of alle þe sennes þa[t] þer beþ Þos bereþ þat los; For euerech senne þat me deþ Longeþ to some of þos. 106 And her-by þou my?t, man, y-seo hou here ende hys sour; Nou loke her-in, pur charite, And make hyt þy myrour. Oretis pro anima domini Willelmi de Schorham, quondam vicarii de chart iuxta ledes, qui composuit istam compilacionem de septem mortalibus peccatis. Et omnibus dicentibus oracionem dominicam cum salutacione angelica, Xl? dies uenie, a domino Symone, Archiepiscopo cantuarie, conceduntur. V. [The Five Joys of the Virgin Mary.] 1 Meche hys þat me syngeþ and redeþ, Of hyre þat al mankende gledeþ Ibore was here on erthe; And þey alle speke, þat spekeþ wyd tonge, Of hyre worschype, and murye sounge, ?et more he were werthe. 2 Þyse aungeles heryeþ here wyþ steuene, Ase he hys hare quene of heue[ne], And eke hare blysse; Ouer al erþe leuedy hys here, And þor?-out helle geþ here power, Ase he hys emperysse. 3 Cause of alle þyse dignyte, Þor? clennesse and humylyte, Was godes owene grace; Wer-þor? he ber þan heuene kyng: Worschype hys worþy ine alle þyng, In euereche place. 4 Al þat hys boue and vnder molde, Hou my?t hyt bote hyt bowe scholde To hyre owene mede? Wanne he þat al þys wordle schel welde To hyre worschipe hys yhelde For here moder-hede. 5 Al þyse maydenes, wyþ-out bost, Hy bereþ god in here goste, In hare holy þou?t[e]; Ac hy wyþ-oute mannes ymone In body, and nau?t in gost a-lone, To manne hyne broute. 6 Of hyre þat hys þos dygne of take, Hou my?te ich of hyre songes make, Þat am so foul of lyue? And þou me bede, soster, synge, And alle in-to one songe brynge Here swete ioyen fyue. 7 To segge þat ich hyt maky can, Þat am so one-connende a man, Dar ich me nau?t auanty; Ac tryste ich wolle to oure leuedy, And maky hyt ase hyt wyle by, And ase hy hy[t] wole me granty. 8 As man ine hys by-leaue yseþ, Ioyen of hyre so fele þer beþ, Ne may hys no man telle, Ase hy haþ of hyre leue sone: Hyt passeþ al mankendes wone, And out of mannes spelle. 9 Four manere ioyen hy hedde here Of hyre sone so lef an dere, Wytnes opan þe godspelle; And al[le] comeþ of þe blysse Þat hye heþ nou, wyþ-oute mysse, So stremes of þe welle. 10 Þe wylle þat hys in paradys Fol wel by-tokneþ þys auys, Wyþ here stremes foure, Þet orneþ out ouer al þat londe, Nys neuer erþlyche man þat fond Hou fele come of þe stoure. 11 Þys wulle hys god self man by-come, Of hym þys ioyen beþ alle y-nome, And alle ine uour manere: Þe furste was wyþ concepcioun, Þo þe angel gabryel come a-doun Ine stede of messager[e], 12 To brynge þe tyþynge by-fore Þat cryst of hyre wolde by bore, Mannes trespas to ?elde, For to brynge ous out of helle: Wo mytte þenche oþer telle Wat ioye þer y uelde! 13 In na?areth, þe ryche toun, Aue maria was þat soun Of gabrieles steuene; Þo was þat mayde wel ygret, And wyþ a present wel ageet Fram vader oure of heuene. 14 So he was ine hyre ycome, For fleasch and blod of hyre to nome, Ase þe angel hyre seyde; Ne hy of mannes mone neste, Ne hy ne brek nau?t hyre by-heste, Ac euere clene a mayde. 15 Seynt johan þe baptyst on-bore, Þo hy spek hys moder by-fore, Ine ioye he gan to asprynge. Ely?abet wel þat aspyde, Hou a spylede onder hyre syde, And made hys reioyynge. 16 More encheyson hadde oure leuedy Ioyous and blyþe for to by, Wyþ-oute prede and boste; For in hyre selue hy hyne fredde, Fol wel hy wyste hou [hy] hyne hedde Þor? self þe holy goste. 17 Ioseph kedde þat he was mylde, Þo þat he wyste hy was wyþ chylde, A-wey he wolde alone; Ha nolde nau?t he were a-slawe, Ne forþe y-iuged by þe lawe To by stend wyþ stone. 18 Ac ioseph was wel blyþe, aply?t, Þo to hym cam þe angel bry?t, To segge hym wat he scholde; Wel blyþþere my?te be þat may, Þat was y-conforted al day Wyþ aungeles wanne hy wolde. 19 In þyssere ioye we scholde by-louken Al hyre ioyen of uourti woken Þe wylest he ?ede wyþ chylde. Of hyre [barme] hyt was god game, Þer-inne þet vnicorn weks tame Þat er þan was so wylde. 20.ii Þet oþer ioye of hyre ycore Was of ihesus, of hyre ybore A crystemasse ny?te, Wyþ-oute sor?e, wyþ-oute sore; And so ne schal þer neuer more Wymman wyþ childe dy?te. 21 For so hy hyne scholde ferst auonge, Þer nes no senne þer amonge, Ne noe flesches lykynge; Þer-fore of hyre y-bore he was, Ase þe sonne passe?t þor? þe glas Wyþ-outen on openynge. 22 In suaþebendes hy hyne dy?te, Ase hyt hys þe chyldes ry?te, And ?ef hym melk to souke; Þa? hyt were þustre of ny?t, Þer nas wane of no ly?t, Þe heuene gan onlouke. 23 Out com an aungel wyþ great leem In-to þe feld of bedleem, Amonges þe schepherden, Te telle þat cryst was ybore; Þer come singinde þer-fore Of angeles manye verden. 24 Þanne sede he swyþe wel Gracia plena, gabryel, And þat hys “fol of grace”; Wanne glorye of hyre hys fol a-boue, And pays igrad for hyre loue Of angeles in place. 25 Þe oxe and asse in hare manyour, Þo þat hy se?en hare creatour Lyggynde in hare forage, Al one-knowynge þa? hy were, Hy makede ioye in hare manere, And eke in hare langage. 26 Ope þe he?e e?tynde day He onder-?ede þe gywen lay, And was ycircumcysed. Iesus me clepede hyne þer-uore, Ase aungeles, er he were ybore, Hys eldren hadde y-wysed. 27 Mochele ioye hy aspyde, Þe kynges þre þat come ryde Fram be easte wel iverre; Gold, myrre, stor, were here offrynges, Þat he was lord and kyng of kynges Wel by-toknede þe sterre. 28 Þo þat he scholde y-offred by In þe templo domini, Ase la?e ?ef þe termes, Symeon, þe olde man, gan crye, And spek of hym fur prophecye, And tok hym ine hys earmes. 29 Þo he was bote twelf wynter ald, And he? ine þe temple he seat wel bald, And þa? he speke smale, Many man wondrede on hym þere, For to alle clerkes þat þer were He ?af answere and tale. 30 Alyue uertu was hys childe-hode, And so he com to hys manhode; Ine flom iordanes syche He was ycrystned, þe heuene onleake, Þe fader of heuene doun to hym spake, Þe gost com coluere ylyche. 31 To þyssere ioye longye scholle Alle þe ioyen þat hyre folle Of hyre chylde god, Fram þan tyme he was ybore For al mankende þat was for-lore, For[t] he deyde one þe roude. 32.iii Þe þrydde ioye þat com of cryste Hadde oure leuedy of hys opryste Fram deaþes harde bende, Out of þe sepulcre þer he laye, Ase hyt fel þane þrydde daye After hys lyues ende. 33 Wet ioye of hym my?te be more After suiche sor?ynge and swyche sore, Ase hye yseye hine feye, Þanne isi?e hyne come to lyue a?en, And euereft more alyue to ben, And neuere eft to dey?e? 34 Þat he was lyf and strengþe and my?te, And þat he kedde on Estre ny?tte, Al ine þe dawyynge: Al þa[t] was an erthe schok, And heuene aboue vnder-toke Hys holy vppe-rysynge. 35 Þar doun come aungeles whyte ine wede, And þat he was aryse hy sede, And hare sawe was trewe; Þat he ne laye nau?t vnder molde For to a-saye, ho so wolde, Þane stone hye ouer-þrewe. 36 Þa? þat he ine hys manhoþ deyde, Dominus tecum þat a seyde, Þo þe aungel here by-redde, (Þat hys to seggene “god es my?tte”), Ine ry?te soþe hyt moste sitte Þet god-hoþ wel hyt kedde. 37 Nedde oure leuedy þyse blysse a-lone, Ac al hyre frendes in hyre mone, So meche was here þe more; For more hijs blysse god and clene Among frendes to habbe ymene, After sor?ynge and sore. 38 O þat hy were blyþe, þo hye (here) se?en So glorious alyue, wyþ here e?en, Þet hy yseye er ine paygne! Furste a schewed hym wyþ a fayre chaunce To here þet hys ensample of repentaunce, Marye magdaleyne. 39 And so hyseye hyne peter, and seþenes hy alle, And þer thomas of ynde, a k[n]owes yfalle, Groped hys holy wounde; Þare he fond flesch and blod myd þe bones, An nou he gan to crye loude for þe nones: “My lord ich abbe y-founde.” 40 Houre lord hym answerde in þet cas: “Þou leuedest, for þou se?e me, thomas, Þat þou me haddest y-founde; Ac, thomas, ich þe telle, yblessed hy beþ, Þo þat on me by-leueþ and nau?t me seþ, Ne gropyeþ none wounde.” 41 To þyssere ioyen scholle by yleyd Alle þe ioyen þat mo?e be yseyd, Ine wyttes oþer in mende, Fram crystes resurreccioun, Wat comeþ hys ascensioun At fourty da?en ende. 42.iv Þe ferþe ioye telle ich may, Þat fel opon þe holy þoresday, Opone a mounteyne he?e; Hi se? ihesus, and oþre some, Of flesch and blod of hyre ynome, Op in-to heuene ste?e. 43 Al ine ioye was hyre mende, Þo hy se?e here and oure kende, Ihesus, hyre leue sone, In-to þe blysse of heuene sty, To agredy worþy scholde hy be At hyre assumpcioun[e]. 44 And ?et ne were hyt no?t y-no? One to agredy hyre loo? And he? ine heuene blysse, Ac oure also, hyt nis non oþer, For he hys oure kende broþer, Þat leue we to wysse. 45 Ine hym ne schal hyt nau?t lang be Þat we to hym ne scholle te, Wanne we scholle wende hennes; Ac schel on ous, þat beþ onkende, Ne dra?eþ nau?t hys loue to mende, And wreþeþ hyne wyþ sennes. 46 And ?et he hys milde and sparyeþ some, And ase he wente op, he wole come A domesday wel bry?te, For te trye manne dede, And after dede ?iue mede And iugement to ry?tte. 47 Betere red nys þer non here For to be crystes yuere, And hy? ine heuene blysse, Bote felþe of senne to by-vly, And bydde god and oure leuedy Þat hy ous helpe and wysse. 48 For hyre poer nys nou?t y-lessed, Ac toup alle oþren hys y-blessed, Soþe wyf and mayde; Ase þat godspel telleþ ous, Benedicta tu in mulieribus, Eli?abeth hyt sayde. 49 Al here ioyen a lok-sounday, And alle þe þät me aspye may, Þat hyre and erþe felle, Al fram crystes ascencioun, Al wat comþe hyre assumpcioun, To þyssere loungy schelle. 50.v Þe fyfte ioye of oure leuedy Not er[þ]lych man hou hyt may by, Ne þer-of [may] more aspye, Bote þat þe gloriouse beerde Out of þyse world (þe) gloriouse ferde, Wyþ greate melodye. 51 One-couþ to þe, man, hys þes figure, For þe offyce of hyre sepulture Was al an heuene gyse; And toller hys man to heuene speche Þanne be a best, þa? man hym teche Reyson and mannes wyse. 52 Þer-fore nys þer-of naut y-wryte, For man ne mot nou?t her y-wyte Wat hys so he? a steuene; Ac holy cherche der wel by-knowe Þat hy ne þolede none deaþes þrowe, Þat loweþ þat lyf of heuene. 53 Hyt hys y-wryte þat angeles brytte To holy manne deaþe aly?te [Þet] her an erþe leye; In holy bok hys hyt inome Þat god hym self a wolde come, Wanne hy scholde deye. 54 Þer-bye we mowe wel y-wyte, Þa? þer be nau?t of y-wryte, Þat cryst hym self was þere; Myd hym of heuene þe ferede, Þe eadi leuedy for to lede, Most here no fend offere. 55 Hy wente vppe, my leue broþer, In body and soule, hyt nys non oþer, For cryst hys god and kende: Þat body þat he tok of hys o?en, Hou mytte hyt ligge a-mang þe lo?en, Wyþ-oute honour and mende? 56 Þanne ich dar segge mid gode ry?te Þat alle þe court of heuene aly?tte Attare departynge; And cryst hym self a?eins hyre com, And body and saule op wyþ hym nom In-to hys wonyynge. 57 Þat hy hys quen, ase ich er mende, Here grace hy may doun to ous sende, Hire ioye to fol-uelle. Ich hopye hy nele nau?t let ous spylle, For he hys al to hyre wylle Of ioye þat hijs þe welle. 58 For of hyre wombe he hys þat frut, Were-of þes angeles habbeþ hare dut, And men hare holy fode; Eli?abeth, hy sede þys: “Et benedictus fructus ventris Tui, iesus þe gode.” 59 Of songe hys to þen ende y-brout, Ase þou hest, soster, me by-so?t, Ase ich hene my?tte frede. Nou syng and byde þe heuene quene Þet hy ous brynge al out of tene At oure mest[e] nede. AmeN. Oretis pro anima Willelmi de Schorham, quondam vicarii de chart iuxta Ledes. VI. [On the Virgin Mary.] 1 Marye, mayde mylde and fre, Chambre of þe trynyte, One wyle lest to me, Ase ich þe grete wyþ songe; Þa? my fet on-clene be, My mes þou onder-fonge. 2 Þou art quene of paradys, Of heuene, of erthe, of al þat hys; Þou bere þane kyng of blys, Wyþ-oute senne and sore; Þou hast y-ry?t þat was amys, Ywonne þat was y-lore. 3 Þou ert þe coluere of noe, Þat broute þe braunche of olyue tre, In tokne þat pays scholde be By-tuexte god and manne; Suete leuedy, help þou me, Wanne ich schal wende hanne. 4 Þou art þe bosche of synay, Þou art þe rytte sarray, Þou hast ybrou?t ous out of cry Of caleng of þe fende; Þou art crystes o?ene drury, And of dauyes kende. 5 Þou ert þe slinge, þy sone þe ston Þat dauy slange golye op-on; Þou ert þe ?erd al of aaron Me dreye ise? spryngynde: Wytnesse at ham euerechon Þat wyste of þyne chyldynge. 6 Þou ert þe temple salomon, In þe wondrede gedeon, Þou hest ygladed symeon Wyþ þyne swete offrynge In þe temple atte auter ston, Wyþ ihesus, heuene kynge. 7 Þou ert judith, þat fayre wyf, Þou hast abated al þat stryf, Olofernes wyþ hys knyf Hys heuede þou hym by-nome; Þou hest ysaued here lyf Þat to þe wylle come. 8 Þou ert hester, þat swete þyng, And asseuer, þe ryche kyng, Þey heþ ychose to hys weddyng, And quene he heþ a-uonge; For mardocheus, þy derlyng, Syre aman was y-honge. 9 Þe prophete ezechyel In hys boke hyt wytnesseþ wel, Þou ert þe gate so stronge so stel, Ac euere y-schet fram manne; Þou erte þe ry?te uayre rachel, Fayrest of alle wymman[ne]. 10 By ry?te toknynge þou ert þe hel Of wan spellede danyel; Þou ert emaus, þe ryche castel, Þar resteþ alle werye: Ine þe restede emanuel, Of wan y-spekeþ ysaye. 11 Ine þe hys god by-come a chyld; Ine þe hys wreche by-come myld, Þat vnicorn þat was so wyld Aleyd hys of a cheaste: Þou hast y-tamed [hyt], and i-styld, Wyþ melke of þy breste. 12 Ine þe apocalyps sent Iohn Ise? ane wymman, wyþ sonne by-gon, Þane mow[n]e al onder hyre ton, I-crouned wyþ tuel sterre; Swych a leuedy nas neuere non, Wyþ þane fend to werre. 13 Ase þe sonne takeþ hyre pas Wyþ-oute breche þor?-out þat glas, Þy maydenhod, on-wemmed hyt was For bere of þyne chylde; Nou, swete leuedy of solas, To ous senfolle be þou mylde. 14 Haue, leuedy, þys lytel songe, Þat out of senfol herte sprong; A?ens þe feend þou make me strong, And ?yf me þy wyssynge; And þa? ich habbe y-do þe wrang, Þou graunte me amendynge. Oretis pro anima domini Roberti Grosseteyte, quondam Episcopi Lincolniae. VII. On the Trinity, Creation, the Existence of Evil, Devils, Adam and Eve, &c. 1 In holy sauter me may rede Hou god þourwe þe prophete sede, Dauyd, y-wysse, Þat fol in hys herte sede: ‘Þer nys no gode,’ dar man nau?t drede To don amys. 2 Seþþe hyt hys so, hyt hys grete doute Þat þare be woxe of þare route Mani a fol, Þat weneþ ryt, wyþ-oute mysse, Þat þer nys god ine heuene blysse, Ne helle pool. 3 Þat eny soche be crystene man, God for-bede! and nau?t for þan, We y-soeþ al day Þat menye y-crystnedde were, Fareþ ryt ase hy nere Nau?t of þe fay. 4 And manye of ham þat beþ so fel[l]e, Þat þa? me godne sckele hem telle, Nau?t hy?t ne ganþ: A?en hy clappeþ þys and þat, And manye of ham not neuere wat, Ne wat he menþ. 5 To sechen hyt hys wel lytel prys Reyson to telle, þet hys y-wys, Ac lete ham be; For, bote hy take a betere fay, Atte last hy goþ to schame a-way, Me may hyt see. 6 Ac ?ef þou wenst, man, þat errour, Þat þare ne be no sauueour Ne oþer lyf, And hyt be for de-faute of lore, Lest now wat ich segge more, Wyþ-oute stryf. 7 And ?ef þou [be] ylered man, And onderstan[s]t ?et al for þan No god ne be, Ich acsy þe a questioun, And, ase hyt longeþ to reysoun, And-swere þou me. 8 Þe erthe hys heuy, wyþ-oute wylle, Þat wey y-seoþ, and by al stylle To gonne þrop. Wat, hou fareþ hy þat hy nasynkeþ, Ase here kende were, hyt þynkeþ; Ho halt ys op? 9 Herto me seyþ, and heþ ysed, To healde hy op hyt nys no ned, Ne neuere nes, For chisel, grauel, stones harde, Ande here depnysse ry?t dounwarde Hys endeles. 10 Þat þat be fals me may aspye By wytnesse of philosophye And clerkes fele; And fals ich may hit prouie wel, Þer hyt hys ned, and were ich schel, By þysse skele. 11 Þe sonne and monne and many sterren By easte aryseþ swyþe ferren, Ase ham y-worþe; By weste hy grendeþ, alle þyse, And comeþ a?en þer hy aryse Al vnder forþe. 12 Þos my?t wete wel, wo-so wolde, Þe wolkne by-clepþ al þe molde, And so hyt doþ; Ne may hy nau?t þanne be endeles Þat þos be-go so hys and wes, An þat hys souþe. 13 Ac saye ry?t þos—and ich afowe Þat euerech man hyt mo?t alowe Þat reson hent:— Hy?t hys a my?t of alle my?tte Þat halt op þerþe and sterren bry?te Aboute itrent. 14 Þys ilke mytte, for hyt wel may, Bryngeþ forþe a wyt of swete aray, Þet no swech nys; For al þat hys an he? and lo?e Hit schift and ditteþ ase hys o?e, And so hyt hys. 15 Wat makeþ sonne, mone, and sterren To certeyn go, aboute and ferren, And faylleþ na?t? Hyt mot wyt and wysdom, neade, Þet of þe mytte þet ich er sede Hys forþe ara?t. 16 Nou þou sixte wel hou hyt syt, Þys ylke my?te and eke þys wyt, In oure boke: Þe mytte hys fader of oure crede, Wysdom þe sone, for wytti-hede Þat he forþ toke. 17 Euer was þys ylke my?tte, And euer worþ, bye gode ryte, Ne say nau?t nay! Hou mytte hyt [cesse], and eft by-gynne, Þet nede neþ of none gynne, Ac al do mey? 18 And ase hyt hys by-fore y-nome, Þa? þat wyt of þe mytte [come] By kende wey, Þat wyt was euere naþeles, Þe my?tte nys neuer wytles, Ne by ne may. 19 Her-to acordeþ oure fay, Þat holy cherche ne? eche day Wel merye syngeþ, Ine a song ofte by note ‘Quicunque uult’ þet hys y-hote, Ry?t ase me singeþ. 20 For þer hyt of þe uader seyþ, And of þe sone to-gadere leyþ, In boke yset: ‘Þe sone hys of þe fader alone Engendred, nau?t ymad of mone, Nef oþe[r] wet.’ 21 Folye hyt hys to meche to þenche Of þe engendrure, and þynne adrenche, Of fader and sone: So ase hy beþe, [hy] euer were, And soche by-?ete neuere nere Elles ine wone. 22 Ac nau?t forþ þan, þat hyt be soþ Holy cherche to wytene doþ, We wyten hyt wel; Ilef hyt, oþer þou ert by-caut, For ho þat nele by-leue hyt nau?t, To helle he schel. 23 And þelke sone ?et naþeles Ry?t ase þe fader hys endeles, Ase my?t and wyt: ?ef euer was [fader], euer was sone, For beþe reysoun and eke wone Aloweþ hyt. 24 Nou we habbeþ uader and sone, Ase hye beþ ry?t ine persone, And þan-cheysoun. Wat may þe holy gost nou be? Persone þrydde in trynyte, Nou herkne reysoun. 25 Þou sixt þet al þat farþ ary?t, Be hyt þyster, be hyt ly?t, To acord hys wyue; For ?ef þer were werre a-boue Amang þe sterren, and no loue, Al hy to-dryue. 26 And bote a truwe loue come Of þare my?tte and þa wysdome, Ne my?t hyt by; And ry?t of ham he moste come, For werof elles te be y-nome Can non ysy. 27 Euer-to lef þat loue were, For my?tte and wysdom neuer nere Wyþ-oute acord; For ?ef acord hem hedde yfaylled, Ar ayder oþer hedde a-saylled Wyþ wykked word. 28 Hou scholde my?tte maky wrake, Oþer eny descord onder-take Wyþ o?e wyt? So nest, ac euer weren hy: Þanne moste loue euer by, Nou þou sixt hyt. 29 Þys loue hys self þat holy spyryt; Þer-to acordeþ holy wry?t Ine þylke songe Þat ich was embe, [of] oure faye, Þat holy cherche singeþ a daye At pryme longe: 30 ‘Þe holy [gost] of [þe] fader ryche And of þe sone, of oþer ylyche, So he for[þ] comeþ; Noþer by-?ete, ne forþe i-wro?t Of a?t þat hys, ne forþe of no?t’: By lawe hyt nomeþ. 31 And euer was þat holy spyry?t, Þat ylke songe wytnesseþ hyt, And more þer-to: Þat he schal by, and hys, and was Ase fader of heuene ry?t endeleas; And sone al-so. 32 ?et oure by-leaue wole onder-gon Þat þyse þre beþ ry?t al on, And nys no wrong; Þa? hy be ine reyson dyuers, O god hyt hys, and stent in uers Ine þulke song. 33 Þa? my?te, wysdom, and eke loue, Hy þre by, ase ich sede a-boue, Diuers ine werk, Ine hem self o god hy beþ; Nys non þat a?t elles y-seþ So god [a] clerke. 34 And naþeles ofte hy beþ y-blent, Þyse clerkes, wyþ here argument, Ande gynneþ le?e; Hare o?e wyt, hyt hym by-kecheþ, Þat god so sotylleche secheþ, Þat syt so he?e. 35 Þe fader hys god, for he may al; Þe sone hys god, for he wot al, Wyþ-out[e] crye; Þe gost hys god, þat oneþ al, ?et ne beþ hy bote o god al, Nau?t godes þry. 36 Þa? my?tte be to þe fader yleyd, And wysdome of þe sone yseyd, And loue þe gost, ?et beþ hy þre of one my?tte, Of one wytte and loue ly?tte, Þor? fay þe hyt wost. 37 Nou þou syxt wel þat encheysoun Of oure by-leue, and eke reysoun, Þet o god hys; ?ef þou þenkest forþer hou hyt may be, Go nau?t to ni? hys maieste, To þenche amys. 38 [N]ou hys al þys by skele ondo, And by-leaue alegged þer-to, Þat god hys he. Nou we moste y-wyte more, Of þyse worldle some lore, Hou hy?t may be: 39 Wader þy[s] worldle euer were, Oþer a some tyme nere, And þo by-gan? Euerte mytte hy nau?t by, Ich schal þe telle reyson wy, Soþe ase ich can. 40 For godes my?tte, ande eke hys wyt, And eke hys wylle, to soffry hy?t So were wo?; For he hys almytty, ase ich er sede, Al-wys, and wyl ine god-hede, Þet hys yno?. 41 Ac ?ef he nedde þys world y-wrou?t, And my?te and couþe, and dede hy?t nou?t, Hyt were amys; Ac hys al-my?tte hys of suche entaylle, And hys al-wyt, hou mytte hyt faylle Of þet god hys? 42 He made hyt al, nys hyt non oþer, And þat of nau?te, my leue broþer, He made hys werke; For er he a-gounne hys work so merye, Nas noþer fourme ne materye, Ne ly?t ne derk. 43 Ne acombre nau?t þy wyt any mo, To meche to þenche hou hyt was þo, Hyt [nys] nau?t worþ; Hou man hyt my?te wete ich not, For so to wytene, ase god hyt wot, Comest þou nau?t forþe. 44 Ac some mey acsy, war god was Þo noþyng of þe worlde nas, Ne great ne smal? Þer þe worlde hys nou, was he, And ?et he hys, and euer schal be, Ihole ouer al. 45 He hedde nede of none gynne, Ne ?et now neþ, to wonye ynne, Þou kepe nym; ?ef þe falþ þrof to be aposed, Sey, god nys nau?t in þer worldle aclosed, Ac hy hys ine hym. 46 Þa? hy nabbe ende ne forþe gol, ?et ouer al he hys y-hol, Wyþ-oute drede; Nau?t o del here, anoþer þere, Ase great body, as hyt were, Þat al by-?ede. 47 Þou wost he may by yþo?t of me Alle yhollyche, and eke of þe Wel betere, ich ply?te; He may by wel ine dyuers lo? Ry?t al at ones, wel yno?: Þat deiþ hys my?tte. 48 Þyse wordle he made, as ich er sede, Al ase hy hys ry?t nou ine dede, And lo? and he?; Ine þe gynynge of holy wryt, Hou he hyt made ry?t þer hyt sy?t, Ich hyt yse?e. 49 Ine da?es sixe he made hyt Ry?t: Heuene and erthe and wolkne bry?t, Þet water te-dy?t, Tren and gras and erþe dre?e, Sonne and mone and sterren grey?e, Þat beþ so bry?t; 50 Fo?eles, fisches ine þe depe, Bestes, wormes for to crepe, And a last, man; So þat hyt was god and sad, Al þys world, þat was ymad Of hym þat can. 51 Al hyt was god, wyþ-oute lak, Hard and nesche, wyte and blacke, And al þat wes: Nedes godes creature Moste be ry?t by nature, Al senneles. 52 ?ef quead so were of gode y-nome, By ry?tte he my?tte be wyþ-nome Ry?t ase a qued; Þer-fore ne my?te he nau?t do wroþe: Ac schrewadnesse beþ hym loþe, And hys for-beade. 53 And seþþe god self hyt for-beade, Wannes comeþ forþe al þat quead, So meche þer hys? And wel to donne apayneþ ueawe, Ac hym apayneþ many a screwe To do amys. 54 Þat god hyt soffreþ, hou mey hyt be, Seþþe of so great my?tte hys he Þet, ?ef ha wolde, He my?tte uordo þat hys quead, And lete ous libbe, and nau?t be dead? Hyt þingþ ha scholde. 55 Leue broþer, ?ef he so scholde, By þe syker þat he so wolde, Ac he hyt nele. Ich kan þe telle reyson wy He let y-worþe quead to by; Nou harkne skele. 56 Þat alþer-ferste þat god schop, Þat was heuene, þer nys no wop, Soþ for to telle; For he hyt made of swyche aray, For alle manere blysse and play Þer to folfelle. 57 Ac o blysse hys, nys nau?t folfeld, War-fore þat heuene hys al ydueld, And ?et nou worþ; Ac ich schel telle wat hys þat blysse, And so we scholle wyte to wysse Hou quead comeþ forþe. 58 ?ef þe by-falþ auancement Of ?efþe þat þe was yment, Wel blyþe art þou; And ?ef þe falleþ to be eyr Of a regne mechel and fayr, More hys þy prou. 59 Ac nys no blysse ne no feste A?eyns þe ioye of conqueste Þet hys þor? god; Ne mey me more ioye aspye, Þane wanne a man þor? pur mestrye Keþ hys manhod. 60 And to great defaute hyt were, ?ef no ioye of conqueste nere, So merye hys hy: Nou sixt þou þanne mytte beste Hou ioye þat comeþ of conqueste Mot neades by. 61 Nys gryt stryf wyþ-oute queade, And þer conqueste hys, stryf hys neade, And som yschent: Þanne nys hyt to god no wrang To soffre queade þe gode amang To auancement. 62 For ?ef quead nere in none þynge, Þer nere stryf ne contekynge, Ne no wyþ-sey; And ?yf stryf nere, ne victorye, So scholde ine heuene [faylly] (þat) glorye, Ac hyt ne mey. 63 Þer-fore þer hys a maystre schreawe, Wyþ hym mo beþ, and þet nau?t ueawe, And neades mote; For he hys heaued of schrewednesse, As god hys cheaf of alle godnesse And alle bote. 64 Hou mytte schreaudnesse by, Bote scherewen were hy Þat hy ferst þou?te? For god ne dede no quead in dede, For al was god, ase ich er sede, Al þat he wroute. 65 Þes ilke screawe so hys ly?t-barn, Þat in-to helle god at-arn Ferst for hys prede; Ac god hyne makede fayr yno?, Bry?t ande schene, and he?est in lo?, Ferst ine hys dede. 66 Ac are he were y-mad parfyt, Ase gode soffrede hy?t, He waux wel proud: He wolde sette hys sete ryche Of north half, and be god ylyche, To be a-lowed. 67 And so he werry ferst by-gan Wyþ gode ine heuene, and ?et te þan Oþer wel fele, Wyþ hym þat helde wyþ alle my?tte, Angeles þat god hedde ymad bry?tte In alle wele. 68 Þys by-ganne schrewednesse Op an he?, ine heuene blysse, Þe ferste day; Hy?t moste neades for þe glorye, Elles hedde y-faylled fyctorye, Ac hyt ne may. 69 Ac alle hy weren ydryuen out, Wyþ lucyfer þat was so stout, Þor? godes my?tte; Hy þat ne hylde wyþ þe left Sta[b]le woxe, þat neuere eft Sene?y ne my?tte. 70 Tuo skeles beþ, þat me may wyte, Þat none nere ymad parfyte Ine heuene ferst, Er þe bataylle yended was By-twexte god and sathanas Þat now hys werst. 71 O reyson was for angeles gode Þat chose ary?t, and faste stode At þylke dede: For þat hy scholde, þor? pur co[n]queste, Habbe ioye euere to leste For hare mede. 72 Þat oþer reyson was for þe deuel, Þat he schal to mys wende hys cheuel Þor? hys malyce, So þat folueld were þe glorye, And hym seelf þor? noble uictorye Lys al hy[s] blysse. 73 ?ef hy hade be mad parfy?t, We nedde y-haued ry?t no profy?t Ine heuene a-boue; Nou schal man be in hare lo?, And habbe ioye and blysse yno?, And pes and loue. 74 And seþþe hyt moste nides by Þet soche schrewen were hy, Ase gode hyt mente, Hou yst þet hy ine helle slabbeþ, And þare-tou none grace nabbeþ To repente? 75 Suppose here hijs o iustyse, God and truwe in alle wyse, And wys of rede; And dampneþ þeues for to ordeyne Peys in londe, nau?t fo[r] weyne, Ne for queadhede. 76 Suppose he þat schel hem spylle, And hongeþ hy wyþ grete wylle, And hys wel glad; Ne he neþ reuthe of hys em-cryste, Þa? hy neuere of þefþe neste: Þes hys a quead, 77 For þat he hys mansle?þe pur, Of wylle of mysauenture, To spylle blod; And he þat mente hyt, þat iustyse Hys to preysy in þysse wyse For hys wyl god. 78 So þou sixte þat me may dy?te Quead for gode, and þat wyþ ry?tte, And so me deþ; And hy þat doþ hyt ine deade, Wyþ hare wyl of schrewed-hede, Dampnable beþ. 79 Þos mo?e we wel by reysoun scheawe Þat, þa? god soffrede such a schreawe Al for to spylle, Hyt was for gode, ase ich er sede, And lucyfer in hys mysdede Was wykke of wylle. 80 And þare-uore dampnable he hys, For he was [glad] to don amys, Þo þat he my?tte; And god soffred þat ylke dede, For god come þrof, ase ich er sede, Ase god hy?t dy?tte. 81 Ne hyt nys of god no malyce Þe? he hym soffrede lese hys blysse And alle hys wele, Al þa? he þor? hys grace my?tte Habbe y-don hym wilni þat ry?tte; Nou harkne skele. 82 Hyt onbycome ine eche place ?ef ech [þ]yng hadde ylyche grace To ioye and blysse; And ich mey ?yuen, and eke wyþ-dra?e, Al þat myn hys, by gode la?e, Wyþ-oute malyce. 83 Ne may nau?t þanne god al-so, War he wyle, hys grace do, And eke wyþ-dra?e, ?ef he wole, wyþ-out malyce, And wyþe-oute alle manere uyce? Nys þys god la?e? 84 ?es, y-wys, god la?e hys: Þet hyt be al ase hys wyl hys Hyt wyle wel by-come; Nys non þat conne dy?te hyt bet, Al-þa? hyt þenche wel on-net, Hys wyl, to some. 85 Þer þat god wyle grace ?eue Euer to libbe, hyt mot leue Ine sauement; And þar he wyle hys grace wyþ-dra?e, Nys nau?t malyce, ac hyt hys la?e And iugement. 86 Ac wy he graunteþ grace to one, And soche and oþeren grauntyeþ none, Segge ich ne kanne; Bote þet hys hys priuete Of hys domes in equyte, Wyþ wyl to þanne. 87 For þer nys nou?t of þysse wylle Her to iugy, ac be we stylle, We beþ y-let; For dauyd ous to wyten deþ, In boke, þat godes domes beþ A groundlyas pet. 88 For hys ne may no wyt areche, Bote þo þet hym self wyle teche He scheawyþ hy, And þe he nele, hy beþ pryue: Al þat y-ordeyned heþ he Mot neades by. 89 Þus þe deuel ydampned hys, And wyþ hym al-so þat beþ hys, Deuelen wel mo; For þat þe grace of god him faylleþ, Moche hys þe pyne þat hem eyleþ, And eke þe who. 90 Wy hy ne mo?e, ase ich er sede, Wel repenty of hare mysdede Lest enne skele, Þat ich schal segge, ase ich can; Mo beþ, ac þet longy te man Ne beþ nau?t fele. 91 Swyþe fayr þyng hys þat wyte, And þer by-syde blak a lyte, Wel ydy?t; Þe wyte hyt þe uayrer makeþ, And [hym] selue more hyt blakeþ, And al hyt hy?t. 92 Þe wyse man þe wyser semeþ Þer þet menye foules dremeþ, And no reysoun; Þe merrer hyt hys ine bataylle Þet me sykþ al þe vomen faylle, And falle a-doun. 93 Þys lykynge hys for heuene blysse, Þat leste schal wyþ-oute mysse Ase euere mo; Þar hys so meche þe more merye Þe deuel ys þat me[y] nau?t ne derye, And helle also. 94 Hy þet þer beþ so mo?e ysy Wat peryl ascaped beþ hy, And be þe blyþere; So þat folueld þe ioye nere, Bote euere helle pyne were, And þrynne wiþere. 95 Ac wo beþ werþer for to by Euer ine helle þanne hy Þer sech gelt hys? Þenne mey be wel þys skele: Þa? grace faylly ham to wele No wonder nys. 96 And ase angeles þe faste stode For heuer eft by-come gode, And glad an blyþe, Ry?t deuelen [so] for screawed-hede Euer mo forse scholle brede, And wreþe and nyþe. 97 Ac þo hy hedde ine heuene ytopped, Wy nedde hy be ine helle y-stopped For euere mo, Ac Nau?t her in þys myddelnerde, For to maky men offerde, And to mysdo? 98 For þo hye weren out ycached, And ou?t of hare lo? arached For hare senne, We mo?e weten hyt wel y-nou Þat al ydel was hare lo? Þat hy weren ynne. 99 And one-by-comeleche þyng hyt were ?ef eny lo? þer leþy were, Seruynde of nou?t[e]; Þar-fore god made mannes schefte, Þat ylke lo? al for to crefte, Ase god hy?t þoute. 100 Ac manne ne mytte nau?t þe glorye Crefte, wyþ-oute victorye, My leue broþer; For ?ef he nadde hy?t þor? conqueste, Folueld ne mytte be hys feste Al ase anoþer. 101 Þare-fore god made hym god and wys, And mayster ouer al paradys, Ac nau?t parfyt; For o trou þ[r]ynne god for-bead, Ase he nolde nou?t be dead, Nau?t take hyt. 102 And god reyson was þat he nere Nau?t parfyt, ase oþer were To-uore ysed; Ac, ase he was y-mad of erþe, Ry?t here an erþe hyt was wel werþe He were asayd. 103 Þer-fore nas helle nau?t y-schet, Ne deuelyn þer-inne nau?t y-det Ine þare crybbe, For þat hy scholde man asaye Waþer he was worþe for to deye Oþer to libbe. 104 Ac þo þe deuel hyt aspyde Þat man hym scholde þer abyde To be assayde, He þou?te gyle al onder-go, For of þet he hadde her ydo He was affrayde. 105 Nas wonder þa? he were affrayd, For swyþe wel he was auayd Of mannes stad; For after god semblant he bere, And he þou?te a þet hym uel er, Þo he was ymad. 106 Ac hys enuie a?eins man So great by-comeþ, þet al for þan He nolde lette Þat he nold[e] man afounde, And an hym, bote he mytte stonde, Hys uenym sette. 107 And dede hym in an addre wede, Þat best was of mest schreuhede, Of alle beste; Hyt moste neades screwed by-come, Þo þat hy[t] hedde ine hym y-nome Soch a tempest[e]. 108 And he gan to þe trowe glyde Þat was for-boden, al forte abyde After hys praye; Ac sore hym drade for to faylly, And dorste nau?t adam asaylly, Al for to waye. 109 Ac wel hym þou?te þat eue nas Na?t so stedefast ase adam was, Þat was hyre lorde; And ase hy come, he gan here knowe, And to hyre speke out of þe trowe Þys ylke word: 110 “Leue dame, say me now, Wy heþ god for-bode hyt ?ow Þet ?e ne mote Eten of al þat frut þat hys Here growynde in paradys To ?oure bote?” 111 “We eteþ y-nou,” quaþ eue, “y-wys, Of alle þe trowes of paradys, And beþ wel gled; Bote þys trow mote we nau?t take, For boþe me and mynne make God hyt for-bede, 112 And seyde, ?ef we þer-of ete, We scholde deye, and lyf for-lete And alle blysse.” “Nay,” quaþ þe fend, “ac ?e ne scholde, Ac he wot fol wel wet he wolde, Þat for-bead þys. 113 He wot wel, ?ef ?e þer-of toke, Wyþ e?en scholde ?e forþ loke Ry?t ase godes, And conne boþe god and quead, And neuer þe raþer be dead For hys for-bodys.” 114 Þos he gan hyre herte ablowe, And hy se? þat frut ine þe trowe Was fayr and god, And et þrof, dame lykerouse, And made ek eten hyt hyre spouse: Hy weren wode. 115 Anon opened þer boþe hare e?en, And naked þat hy weren y se?en, And woxe of-schamed; Wyþ leaues hy helede hem þer-fore; Ne mytte hy no leng be for-bore To be y-blamed. 116 Ac þo hy herde god speke, Wel sone an hal by-gonne þreke, Wer þet hy mytte. “Adam,” quaþ god, “wer my?tou be?” Queþ he: “lord, þo we herde þe, We were of fly?te; 117 And nedes moste, lord, to soþe, Al for þat we beþ naked boþe, Ase uole þynges.” Queþ god: “ho haþ y-scheawed ?ou Þat ?e beþ boþe naked nou, Bote ?oure Etinges?” 118 Sede adam wyþerlyche to gode: “Nedde ich y-broke nau?t þy for-bode, Ne nau?t do so, Nedde þe wymman, lord, y-be Þat to fela?e þou madest me, Hy dede me hyt do.” 119 Þo seyde god almy?ty to eue: “Wy madest þou man mys-byleue, And þous mys-went?” Ac þo seyde eue: “so wey þat wyle! Þe eddre, lord, wyþ hyre gyle Heþ ous y-schent.” 120 Þo by-gan god speke to þat worm: “For þou areredst þerne storm And alle þys hete, Acorsed be þou bestes by-syde, Opone þy wombe þou schalt glyde, And erþe frete. 121 And ich schal makye contekhede By-tuyce þyne and wyues sede, And moche to pleity; So schal þy power be by-reued, Þat ?et schal wymman trede þine heued, And þou hyre wayti.” 122 So sede he wymman here lere, Hou hy scholde al hyre children bere Ine sor?e and stryf, And þet hy scholde lybbe her Euere ine mannes daunger Al hyre lyf. 123 To adam seyde god of heuene: “For þou dedest by þine wyues steuene Þet was for-hote, Þer[þe] hys acorsed ine þyne deade, In swinched þou schalt þy lyf leade, And ete ine swote, 124 Al wat þou art a?en ycome In-to erþe þat þart of ynome, Þor? deaþes bende; For þou nart bote of poudre y-welt, And a?en into poudre schelt, Manne, at þyne ende.” 125 Þor? þe fend, þat hys oure uo, Þos by-ganne ferst al oure wo Þet we beþ inne; An þos by-ganne ferst trecherye Þor? þe feend, and ek enuye, Manne for to wynne. 126 And wonderuol was þys assay, And wonder-lyche ?ede man a-way, Ly?tlyche y-lore; Ac wonder-lyche ?et forþ myt þan Her ine þys world hys euer man To sorwe y-bore. 127 Ac, crystene man, for al þys wounder, Loke þat þou ne go nau?t onder Þor? wantrokynge; For soþe apreued hys þys sa?e, Boþe by þe elde and nywe la?e, Wyþ-oute lesynge. 128 And ske[l]fol was þys ordinaunce, Þa? man by-uolle so hard a chaunce Þor? trycherye; For þor? mestrye þat he uorþ dro? Þe feend in heuene lias hys lo?, Þor? pur mastrye. 129 Ry?t al-so, þo he gyle þou?te, For to brynge man to no?te Pryuelyche, God almy?ty, þat hys wyl wyste, A?eyns hym þo?te go by lyste Al so styllyche. 130 For ine þe trowe deaþ was kene, And þat god made wel y-sene, Þet hyt for-bead; And he weste þat god hyt sede, ?ef man þrof ete he scholde awede, And eke be dead. 131 Ac lyf was al-so ine þe trowe, Ac þat ne my?te be nau?t y-knowe, For god hyt hedde; For hyt was pryue for a wyle A?e þe fendes priue gyle Þe man for-ledde. 132 For nau?t nas hyt ycleped ne hys Trou of lyue in paradys, Ac wyste; For, ase man was þor? trowe by-cou?t, In trowe he scholde be for-bou?t, Þat þe fende neste. 133 And þat was ine þe holy rode, Þor? þe schedynge of þe blode Of godes sone, Ase ich her-after telle may, Þat he tok of a clene may A?eyns wone. 134 Hedde he wyst þer hedde ybe Lyf for-boute ine þe appeltre, He nedde assaylled Noþer adam ne non of hys; Ac are þe worlde was al þys Was y-conseyled. 135 God wyste wel þat man schold erry, And þor? on-boxamnesse uerry Fram alle healþe; Þer-fore þat consayl was wel trye A?eyns þe feendes foule enuie To abatye welþe. 136 Þys consayl, hou hyt scholde be, Al was y-consayled of þre Ere eny tyme, Of fader and sone and holy gost, Þat ich was embe, ase þou wel wost, Ferst in þyse ryme. 137 And was þat conseyl so ytayled, Þat hyt ne my?te habbe faylled To bote of manne, And certeyn tyme yset þer-to, And hou hyt scholde be y-do, And wer and wanne. 138 And her mankende swank and dalf Fy?f þousend wynter and an half, And ?et wel mo, Er þane þe tyme of lyue come, And deaþ man hedde for hys dome And helle also. 139 Þet go[d] so longe abod, þe skele Wel mey be þys, þat on of uele: To mannes mende; For deaþ scholde hys meystryes keþe, And [man] forsopie and for-seþe In deaþes bende, 140 Þat [he] my?te ry?t wel y-knowe Þat he was ry?t al oue[r]-þrowe And harde y-nome; And þe fend hy?t my?te wene Þet men out of so longe tene Ne my?te come. 141 Ac her aryst a questio[u]n: Þo þat adam was bro?t a-doun And eue al-so, Wet gelt hedden hy þat þo nere, Þet hy to deþe ischape were, And eke to wo? 142 Þou syxt, broþer, by þan by-fore, Þat oure aldren were al for-lore, Adam and eue; For þar nas of ham no partye Þat nas torned to vylanye, So to by-leue. 143 Ac now be wey of ham y-come, Wyþ flesch and blod of ham i-nome, Þet was ablowe Þor? þe fenym of þe fende; Þanne falþ ous rewelyche by kende To soffry wowe. 144 And þos þat chyld to ny?t y-bore, Þa? hyt deyde, hyt were for-lore ?ef crystnynge nere, Þor? þe flesch þat hyt nome Of hys eldren þat hyt of come, Þat wykkede were. 145 And neades moste [hyt], leaue broþer, Ry?t of ham come, and man of oþer, And be nature; For elles nadde man y-be Nau?t y-lych gode in trynyte Þor? engendrure. 146 Þa? hy be þor? senne demeyned, So nas hyt nau?t ferst y-ordeyned, Þy[s] engendrure; For þo man senne?ed in paradys, Al chaungede þat flesch a-mys To mysauenture. 147 Elles nedde hyt be no senne, Þy[s] engendrure of al mankenne In al þys wone, Ac senne-leas hyt hadde ybe, Ase þe engendrure in trynyte Of fader and sone. 148 Ase mannes ylyche ymad of tre May nau?t be al ase man may be Inne alle þynge, Ne godes ylyche, man, y-wys, Ne may nau?t be al ase god ys, Of heuene kyng. 149 For god, þe fader, hys leue sone Engendrede out of alle wone, Wyþ-oute tyde; Ac man haþ certayn tyme of elde Wanne he may engendrure ?elde, And tyme abyde.
